Rick Scott (R-FL)2020-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisYOUR WORLD WITH NEIL CAVUTO4:00 PM ESTMichael Burgess, David Kessler, Rick Scott, Russel Honore, Stacey CunninghamNEWSDomestic031901cb.140Coronavirus Cases Grow; Interview with Former FDA Commissioner David Kessler; Interview with Rep. Michael Burgess (R-TX); Interview with Russel Honore; Interview with NYSE President Stacey Cunningham; Interview with Sen. Rick Scott (R-FL)Maria Bartiromo, Nicole Saphier, John Roberts, Bill Hemmer, Susan Li

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Stocks are up at the close on Wall Street, as the president tries to free up more drugs to combat the coronavirus, all this as he meets via video with governors, as they try to beef up the country's response to this pandemic.

Welcome, everyone. Good afternoon. I'm Maria Bartiromo, in this afternoon for Neil Cavuto. This is "Your World."

We are tracking all of it this afternoon with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, along with Republican Senator Rick Scott, on just how Washington is responding, Lieutenant General Russel Honore on how our leaders are leading, and the president of the New York Stock Exchange on floor traders who soon won't be trading on the floor, at least not in person.

First to John Roberts. He's at the White House, where they are trying to fast-track potential coronavirus prescription drugs -- John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good afternoon to you.

The president on his way back from FEMA at this moment after a teleconference with the nation's governors, as the State Department issued a new travel advisory for people who are either overseas or planning to go overseas, the State Department saying -- quote -- "U.S. citizens who live in the United States should arrange for immediate return to the U.S., unless they are prepared to remain abroad for an indefinite period. If you choose to travel internationally, your travel plans may be severely disrupted, and you may be forced to remain outside of the United States for an indefinite period of time."

On Capitol Hill today, the Treasury secretary and other White House officials meeting with lawmakers about the phase three financial stimulus. One of the big components, checks to taxpayers. The way it looks like it might work, is $1,200 per adult up to $75,000 in yearly income, a smaller amount for those who make up the $99,000, and $500 per child.

In the daily coronavirus briefing this morning, the president optimistic that some treatments may be available soon, one of them from Gilead Pharmaceuticals called remdesivir, another an existing anti-malarial drug called hydroxychloroquine.

The president saying, if either one of those becomes available, it could really change the whole computation here. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine works, or any of the other things that they're looking at that are not quite as far out, but if they work, your numbers are going to come down very rapidly. So we will see what happens.

But there's a real chance that they might -- they might work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: Now, of course, yesterday, the president signing the Defense Production Act, which would allow him to guide companies into ramping up quickly inventories of much needed medical supplies.

But the president holding off on that for now, despite calls from the Democratic leadership that he needs to put that into action right now. I asked the president about that this morning. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: You enabled, I guess, is probably the best way to put it, the Defense production Act yesterday, but you didn't pull the trigger on it.

TRUMP: No, because we hope we're not going to need that.

Governors are supposed to be doing a lot of this work, and they are doing a lot of this work. And they are doing a lot of this work.

The federal government is not supposed to be out there buying vast amounts of items and then shipping. We're not a shipping clerk.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: And we keep ticking down on the president's 15-day guidelines to slow the spread of the coronavirus, but indications from the surgeon general, Jerome Adams, today that 15 days may not be enough.

What does the president think? Listen here.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I hope very soon. We will see. This is uncharted territory, as you know. We think we have ideas. It doesn't help to say what the idea is.

I would hope very soon. We're -- we pull together as a nation. People are, for the most part, doing what they're supposed to be doing. The social distancing is very interesting, a whole new term that has become a hot -- it's become somewhat of a hot term, but people are listening, and they're - - and they're really doing a great job.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: So, will, at the end of the 15 days, the president's guidelines have to be renewed for another 15 days? No one really knows. And when asked about it, the president said, I will tell you that when we get to day 14 -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Well, it's incredible, because this was a real market mover, John. Markets were down early on today, but then they picked up as the president talked about this fast-tracking of some drugs.

Fox Business' Susan Li is keeping track of that. And she's on that angle -- Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Well, Maria, a small recovery from the three-year lows that we saw on the stock market. And there is hope of a big economic stimulus plan and packets from the government, also the Federal Reserve injecting a trillion dollars or more overnight.

So are other global central banks over in Europe as well. So we had big tech today leading the way back, Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Microsoft seeing some sizable gains, getting some bids today, and Amazon higher, despite reporting a first warehouse worker testing positive for COVID-19.

So, the coronavirus, yes, depressing stock market, but, really, it's the one two combo of a collapse in prices combined with a spread and a pandemic of coronavirus.

Today, though, take a look at this. We saw the biggest one-day jump in oil prices in history. And this is after President Trump said that the U.S. might be intervening, with Russia and Saudi Arabia cutting prices, and still pumping a lot of oil. Oil is still down over 60 percent on the year.

And, meantime, you heard President Trump saying that he will make chloroquine, a malaria drug, available for COVID-19 treatment. Well, generic drugmakers rallied on the back of this news, Teva, Mylan up in the session.

Gilead Sciences will produce results of its possible coronavirus vaccine called remdesivir next month. And as you see, we're seeing gains for Gilead Sciences.

Now, as for the broader U.S. economy, most investment banks are predicting a sharp decline in the U.S. economy contracting. J.P. Morgan says it'll shrink 14 percent from March to June. Bank of America, Maria, is looking for a 12 percent contraction, job losses of a million a month, and the jobless rate doubling.

And they say, in fact, Maria that the recession is already here.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And these numbers are so stark, 14 percent contraction.

You have got all hands on deck trying to reverse this trend that we are hearing so much about. Susan, thank you so much.

It is not just some potential new drugs. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin also putting all hands on deck, including stimulus. He spoke with me this morning on "Mornings With Maria" over on FOX Business. And he said they are working hard to get hundreds of billions of dollars into the hands of the American people, who have been hit hard by this crisis.

He's looking for that in a matter of weeks.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, U.S. TREASURY SECRETARY: A second component -- and I refer to this as checks in the mail, but that's -- it's really money direct- deposited. Most people, we have all their information.

And the plan is $500 billion in two tranches. The first one would be $1,000 per person, $500 per child. So, for a family of four, that's a $3,000 payment. As soon as Congress passes this, we'd get this out in three weeks.

And then, six weeks later, if the president still has a national emergency, we will deliver another $3,000. So that's a lot of money to hardworking Americans who are at home, no fault of theirs.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: A lot of money, but will it be enough to get Americans back on their feet?

Florida Republican Senator Rick Scott, who is self-isolating right now because of this virus, he joins me right now by telephone.

And, Senator, it's good to see you. Thank you very much.

First off, how are you doing? Are you showing any symptoms?

SEN. RICK SCOTT (R-FL): No.

Maria, I'm self-quarantined because I was around somebody with the president of Brazil that tested positive. So, to make sure I'm safe for everybody that I come in contact with, I self-quarantined last week. And I will finish next -- this coming Monday.

I take my temperature all the time. It's the first indication. And I have not a temperature the whole time.

So, what I have been doing since then...

BARTIROMO: That's...

SCOTT: ... is talking to mayors and state officials and police chiefs and sheriffs and hospitals.

I mean, I'm doing everything I can to move this process along. I think, Maria, you -- and I think you have talked a little bit, the biggest thing we can do, the biggest stimulus we can do, we got to figure out -- figure this out, keep people safe, get them a vaccine.

And so that's why we got these testing sites up now. We have got to self- quarantine and slow this down.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SCOTT: And then we got to do everything we can to rebuild this economy.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right, Senator. Yes, thank you for your leadership, to be doing all that you're doing at home, while you also self-isolate.

We're seeing really an incredible effort by government officials. And I know that the nation thanks you and all the leaders for doing that.

What do you make of the president's plan here? Secretary Mnuchin just talking with me earlier this morning, and we ran that sound bite, talking about the money that will go to people directly. He's talking about three weeks.

There's some debate about needing that money in three weeks, or should small business in particular get some relief now?

SCOTT: Here's I believe.

I believe, one, focus on the people that have been impacted, the hourly workers, the tip workers that right now have gotten impacted. So how do we help them? And how do we help our small businesses?

The first thing that we can do is get them a moratorium on their rent, their mortgage, the utilities, their taxes. That will put money -- that will keep money in their pocket, rather than something they have to spend right now, do it for our small businesses, do it for people making less than $75,000 a year.

And then focus on our existing unemployment system that all of our companies have paid into. Florida has $4 billion in the bank. How do we use that existing system to help all these individuals? Maybe we have to change the rule to say, if you got your hours cut a little bit, you still get it, or if your wages got cut some.

So what we want is, we want our businesses, all of our businesses that we can to stay in business as long as possible.

BARTIROMO: Right.

But you said yesterday that the federal government cannot solve every problem. And this is a sentiment that many people agree with you on, because you really need to see the American people not rely so much on government.

For example, Larry Kudlow had an idea that, if government is going to be using this money for bailouts to be sending out, then maybe the government should be taking stakes in certain companies.

What do you say to that?

SCOTT: Well, first off, if we're going to -- if the government's going to do a bailout, they clearly ought to get a return on it.

This is taxpayer money. But reality is exactly what you just said. We have got to help each other. Each family member has got to help other family members.

BARTIROMO: Right.

SCOTT: Their churches have to help each other.

Our -- all of our community, our local community, that's where everything gets done in this world. We have got to all step up and say, who's hurting? How do we help them? And how did -- the federal government can pay for things...

BARTIROMO: Sure.

SCOTT: ... but that's not the key to this.

The key is helping each other.

BARTIROMO: Senator, it's good to see you. Thanks very much for joining us this morning -- this afternoon. Thank you.

SCOTT: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: We will talk with you soon, Senator Rick Scott.

It is certainly quiet on the streets of New York today and all week. Quite so on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Come Monday, it will be a ghost town down on Wall Street, the NYSE shutting down floor operations over COVID-19.

What does that mean for your money? The president of the New York Stock Exchange is here next.

BARTIROMO: World War II, 9/11, and now COVID-19, major events forcing the New York Stock Exchange to close its floor trading.

And that is where we find ourselves today. That is the deal beginning Monday. But the exchange will be open for electronic trading.

So, how's it going to impact everyday investors?

Joining us right now to talk more about that, we talk with the president of the New York Stock Exchange, Stacey Cunningham.

Stacey, thanks very much for joining me once again.

This is a big deal, closing the trading floor for a period of time. What are your expectations?

STACEY CUNNINGHAM, PRESIDENT, NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE: You know, it is a big deal, Maria.

We haven't closed the trading floor, as you mentioned -- there are few historic moments where the trading floor has been closed.

What's different about this time is that electronic trading will continue. So, that part of it is different. We run multiple markets. We run five equity exchanges, two options markets. Many of them trade fully electronically.

The New York Stock Exchange introduces the human judgment element on top of stock trading. That leads to dampening volatility during times of stress. And as we have seen lately, the markets have been pretty volatile.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CUNNINGHAM: So, we were hanging on to try and keep that extra added protection into the market.

But it got to a point where we just were concerned. We couldn't guarantee that people were going to be able to be protected, their health. So, while we're seeing how the virus unfolds and steps that we can continue to take, we're temporarily shifting to fully electronic, until we can get that -- have more clarity around that situation.

BARTIROMO: So, what are your expectations in terms of how long this lasts?

Stacey, when we spoke earlier this week on FOX Business on "Mornings With Maria," you said, look, if there's a situation where we need human interaction, where we need that extra buying or selling to balance out a trade, we have it here on the floor of the NYSE.

Are you worried that you will not have that component now with electronic trading only?

CUNNINGHAM: I do think we will see some added volatility.

I will give you an example. Last Friday, when the president announced that he was going to fill the oil reserves, it was just a few minutes before the closing auction. And we saw massive buy orders coming into the -- into the market right at that close.

The traders here on the floor were able to go solicit offsetting sell orders, so that they could dampen that volatility and reduce price swings.

BARTIROMO: Sure.

CUNNINGHAM: And so that's an important function that they're able to deliver. When we go fully electronic, you don't see that same effect.

So, yes, I do think it's going to add to a little bit of -- additional volatility in an already volatile period of time. So that's concerning. From an operations perspective, I'm confident it'll work smoothly. So stocks will still open and close. Traders will still be able to send their interest in. And things will trade normally.

I just expect you're going to see additional volatility around the edges. And that's unfortunate, given how the markets are already dealing with so many price swings.

BARTIROMO: Stacey, let me move away from the operations of this, because we clearly understand why you're closing the trading floor for a temporary period of time.

You have got, what, a couple hundred people on the floor right now?

CUNNINGHAM: Yes, there are a few hundred people.

And I will say this is a very patriotic group, Maria.

BARTIROMO: OK.

CUNNINGHAM: So they're looking to come back as soon as possible.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

urn:contentItem:5YBG-2F61-F03R-N2WW-00000-00Coronavirus chaos creates an 'attractive entry point' for internet stocks, UBS says2020-03-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisCoronavirus chaos creates an 'attractive entry point' for internet stocks, UBS saysBen Winck

Mar 02, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Reuters Investors looking to buy the dip amid coronavirus volatility should shift cash to internet stocks, UBS[1] analysts said Friday. The outbreak has driven spikes in the usage of online streaming, tutoring, and medical consultation services, and the risk of increased time indoors could further boost the sector, according to the bank. The sector faces risks from antitrust regulation around big tech firms and connections to the travel industry, the bank warned. UBS recommends exposure to the Nasdaq Internet Index, which includes stakes in Netflix[2], Facebook[3], Amazon[4], and other household names.

Visit the Business Insider homepage for more stories.[5]Internet stocks offer "some relief" for investors with little appetite for coronavirus risks, analysts at UBS[6] wrote Friday. US stocks posted a strong rebound Monday, ending a streak of losses that pushed indices deep into correction territory[7] through the end of February. Yet some experts are calling the relief rally premature[8] and warning investors to stay defensive until more is known of the coronavirus outbreak's trajectory. The epidemic remains a dire source of volatility for risk assets, and Treasury bonds' record-low yields[9] make it more expensive than ever to park cash in the popular safe-haven. The growing risk of coronavirus becoming a pandemic is weighing on investors' desire to stay exposed to stocks, but the recent sell-off presents an alluring opportunity in internet equities, according to UBS. The heightened market volatility reminded the bank's analysts "of the power of the internet," and the chance for new quarantine orders in the near term could boost usage of popular online services, UBS said. The team pointed to recent spikes in the use of online medical consultation, tutoring, and streaming services since the outbreak began. The Nasdaq Internet Index — which includes internet giants such as Facebook[10], Netflix[11], and Amazon[12] — grants investors exposure to a diverse set of firms that could gain from populations spending more time indoors, UBS said. "We view the recent market sell-off as an attractive entry point, and the stay-at-home nature of the companies offer some shelter relative to the broader market," the team of analysts wrote. The index's biggest risk is its holding of travel-related firms, the team added, as the sector remains under considerable pressure from the epidemic. Major airlines swiftly halted travel to and from heavily afflicted regions in recent weeks, and further expansion of the outbreak could drag further on travel and tourism companies. UBS also alerted clients to the latent risk that the biggest companies in tech remain under regulatory scrutiny for data privacy controversies and antitrust concerns. Calls from lawmakers and Democratic presidential candidates to break up big tech firms have prompted some worry around whether the household names will stay the same if a regulation-friendly administration takes office. The bank remains positive on the sector despite fresh regulatory stresses. Shifting cash to internet companies before markets resume their bullish climb gives investors "one way to gain equity exposure to the pockets of the market that are well," UBS said. The Nasdaq Internet Index gained 2.7% in Monday's trading session. urn:contentItem:60V4-NRW1-JCNX-32NP-00000-00Coronavirus could create a lockdown generation in Latin America if governments don't act2020-09-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisCoronavirus could create a lockdown generation in Latin America if governments don't act

Link to Image

Link to Story

Coronavirus has hit the healthcare systems and societies of the global south even harder than the rest of the world due to their already weak economies and high debt levels . Latin America is no exception, and has been particularly affected due to very high infection numbers. With more than 7.9 million cases and more than 300,000 deaths , the region has been described as the world's worst hit region. That is why, according to the World Bank's June assessment , the Latin American economy will contract 7.2% in 2020 as a whole. What's more, some of the promising, if modest, trends of the last two decades are being reversed by the pandemic.

This was a region that was starting to reduce huge levels of inequality thanks to significant economic growth from the commodity boom that ended in 2013, as well as some innovative wage policies and social programmes introduced by progressive governments. Within this context, younger people are being especially badly hit . School closures are hurting education and, as in many countries, job prospects for them are particularly bad. If the region cannot control the virus and kickstart its economy, we will see the growth of a 'lockdown generation', trapped in unemployment, informal jobs and in-work poverty.Unemployment and the gig economyBoth the quantity and quality of jobs are deteriorating rapidly as a result of the economic paralysis created by the pandemic. The UN's International Labour Organization estimates that the health crisis will push unemployment rates in the region up from 8.1% to 11.5% in 2020, the equivalent of more than 11.5 million newly unemployed. As a result, an extra 30 million are expected to fall into poverty (and these estimates were made in May, before the effects of the virus really took hold). Young people will be disproportionately affected, having already been enduring unemployment rates that were three times higher than that of older adults before the pandemic.But it's the historically high level of informal work in Latin America that will make the recovery much more difficult. Before the pandemic, more than half of the workforce across the region was in informal and precarious employment, with no social protections like sick pay or even written contracts. Again, young people make up an even higher proportion of this informal workforce.
Young people are particularly vulnerable to the economic effects of coronavirus. EPA-EFE/JUAN IGNACIO RONCORONI With economies contracting due to the pandemic, even more people are turning to gig work throughout the region in search of a daily income. But this comes with costs . Relying on work as a courier, taxi driver or providing cleaning services through an app was already a tough job. It's generally low-paid and circumvents minimum-wage laws, as workers are classed as self-employed or they simpy work outside of all national labor laws. It's precarious, offering no job security or benefits like sick pay or paid holidays. It's also very isolating, as you are generally working on your own, and it offers very little in the way of career prospects.Risks and rewardsWith the pandemic, the risks involved with gig work increased considerably as these workers come into contact with so many different people. But the pandemic also brought demand for these services, with more people ordering groceries and takeaways under lockdown, or taking taxis instead of public transport. Yet life as a gig worker has not improved. Across Latin America these key workers have reported a lack of support in terms of personal protective equipment and health insurance. Huge numbers also say their incomes have stayed the same or even worsened, despite carrying out more jobs. In one survey of 298 drivers across 29 cities, 64% said their pay had dropped. This is due to changes in the terms offered by companies.
Delivery drivers demonstrate in Mexico City to demand job improvements amid the coronavirus pandemic. Sashenka Gutierrez/EPA-EFE Thousands have protested for better pay and rights. The last couple of months have seen strikes by delivery drivers in cities across the region, including Argentina , Brazil , Colombia and Mexico. Different app companies operate there but the demands are the same: for better pay from the companies and better regulation from governments to prevent exploitation.The lack of regulation is a big part of the problem. It allows the dark side of the gig economy to develop: a growing pool of workers with no employment protection, underpaid with few other job options, and little power to negotiate with big tech companies managing their workforce through algorithms.Latin America's recovery from coronavirus will require significant change to the region's labour markets. Without better protection from underemployment and in-work poverty, the region risks making inequality worse again. Listening to the demands of striking gig workers is a good place to start.

urn:contentItem:60V4-XSC1-JB75-901B-00000-00Coronavirus could create a lockdown generation in Latin America if governments don't act2020-09-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisCoronavirus could create a lockdown generation in Latin America if governments don't actLuciana Zorzoli, Lecturer in Employment Relations & HR Management, Cardiff Business School, Cardiff University

The historically high level of informal work in Latin America will make its recovery much more difficult than elsewhere.

Coronavirus has hit the healthcare systems and societies of the global south even harder than the rest of the world due to their already weak economies and high debt levels. Latin America is no exception, and has been particularly affected due to very high infection numbers. With more than 7.9 million cases and more than 300,000 deaths, the region has been described as the world's worst hit region. That is why, according to the World Bank's June assessment, the Latin American economy will contract 7.2% in 2020 as a whole.

What's more, some of the promising, if modest, trends of the last two decades are being reversed by the pandemic. This was a region that was starting to reduce huge levels of inequality thanks to significant economic growth from the commodity boom that ended in 2013, as well as some innovative wage policies and social programmes introduced by progressive governments.

Within this context, younger people are being especially badly hit. School closures are hurting education and, as in many countries, job prospects for them are particularly bad. If the region cannot control the virus and kickstart its economy, we will see the growth of a "lockdown generation", trapped in unemployment, informal jobs and in-work poverty.

Unemployment and the gig economy

Both the quantity and quality of jobs are deteriorating rapidly as a result of the economic paralysis created by the pandemic. The UN's International Labour Organizationestimates that the health crisis will push unemployment rates in the region up from 8.1% to 11.5% in 2020, the equivalent of more than 11.5 million newly unemployed.

As a result, an extra 30 million are expected to fall into poverty (and these estimates were made in May, before the effects of the virus really took hold). Young people will be disproportionately affected, having already been enduring unemployment rates that were three times higher than that of older adults before the pandemic.

But it's the historically high level of informal work in Latin America that will make the recovery much more difficult. Before the pandemic, more than half of the workforce across the region was in informal and precarious employment, with no social protections like sick pay or even written contracts. Again, young people make up an even higher proportion of this informal workforce.

With economies contracting due to the pandemic, even more people are turning to gig work throughout the region in search of a daily income. But this comes with costs. Relying on work as a courier, taxi driver or providing cleaning services through an app was already a tough job. It's generally low-paid and circumvents minimum-wage laws, as workers are classed as self-employed or they simpy work outside of all national labor laws. It's precarious, offering no job security or benefits like sick pay or paid holidays. It's also very isolating, as you are generally working on your own, and it offers very little in the way of career prospects.

Risks and rewards

With the pandemic, the risks involved with gig work increased considerably as these workers come into contact with so many different people. But the pandemic also brought demand for these services, with more people ordering groceries and takeaways under lockdown, or taking taxis instead of public transport.

Yet life as a gig worker has not improved. Across Latin America these key workers have reported a lack of support in terms of personal protective equipment and health insurance. Huge numbers also say their incomes have stayed the same or even worsened, despite carrying out more jobs. In one survey of 298 drivers across 29 cities, 64% said their pay had dropped. This is due to changes in the terms offered by companies.

Thousands have protested for better pay and rights. The last couple of months have seen strikes by delivery drivers in cities across the region, including Argentina, Brazil, Colombia and Mexico. Different app companies operate there but the demands are the same: for better pay from the companies and better regulation from governments to prevent exploitation.

The lack of regulation is a big part of the problem. It allows the dark side of the gig economy to develop: a growing pool of workers with no employment protection, underpaid with few other job options, and little power to negotiate with big tech companies managing their workforce through algorithms.

Latin America's recovery from coronavirus will require significant change to the region's labour markets. Without better protection from underemployment and in-work poverty, the region risks making inequality worse again. Listening to the demands of striking gig workers is a good place to start.

urn:contentItem:5YB4-S191-JCMN-Y1YD-00000-00Coronavirus (COVID-19) and Big Tech2020-03-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisCoronavirus (COVID-19) and Big TechShelly Palmer

Mar 01, 2020( Shelly Palmer Digital Living: http://www.shellypalmer.com/category/blog/ Delivered by Newstex) There have been calls to break up big tech. People are scared that without regulation, we are destined to live in a 'surveillance state.' But people are also scared of coronavirus (COVID-19). Is this the moment that big tech proves that big data can be used for the greater good?

What is big tech's role in the fight against coronavirus? What should it be?A Grand VisionAs I think about how big tech might lead the fight against COVID-19, the first thing that comes to mind is that data is more powerful in the presence of other data. The more complete the data set, the more you can learn from it. Which means enemies, frenemies, competitors, and compatriots must all join together to win the fight. This requires leadership, but it also requires something we've never had before: a universal database of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) and Protected Health Information (PHI).The Life StarIf you had enough information from the search engines (all of them, not just Google), you would know where people were getting sick. If you had enough information from the social networks (all of them, not just Facebook and Twitter), you would know when people were starting to feel ill. If you had enough PHI, you would know who was getting sick and who was more or less likely to get sick. The data sets would be huge, but there are well-understood predictive tools you would use to give governments and health officials advanced warnings and assessments of risk. This would allow business as usual until a level of risk had been reached, and then preemptive measures could be used to protect people in a given risk zone. Lives would be saved. The economy would feel the minimum impact. There are many good things that could come from analyzing and using the data in this 'grand vision' database.The Death StarNo one (not even the black-ops data miners) have ever put this much PII and PHI together in one place. Bad actors would find this treasure trove of data irresistible. I cannot imagine all of the horrible, evil stuff you could do with a data set this complete. It would be marketing heaven, but a living hell. You could mine it to offer low-cost insurance to the healthiest and deny insurance to the least healthy, then do the same thing with mortgages, bank loans, credit cards, housing, car insurance, and on and on. The list is endless. I know calling this 'The Death Star' is an unfortunate metaphor, but this kind of information could literally be used to deny sick people the insurance they need to obtain life-saving healthcare. What Should We Do?On one hand, this data exists. Right now, it is in many different places in many different databases. It can be gathered. It can be analyzed. And we could save tens of thousands of lives. On the other hand, amassing this database would empower even the most altruistic and good natured among us to wonder about alternative uses.Big Tech LeadershipThis is where big tech leadership comes in. There are ways to hash this data and keep it anonymous. We can mine the information we need without exposing individual identities - it will be very difficult to accomplish (not technically, sociologically). Big tech would have to pick a leader or leaders, and they would have to rally IT professionals and CEOs across many industries. The big tech leadership would have to convince people that there is a safe way to use big tech's power for the greater good.Broken PromisesI've been hearing about the value of the 'free and open' Internet since it was conceived. In hindsight, none of the promises of social media or about the free flow of information have turned out to be true. We have an unending river of unfiltered information that is highly polluted by algorithmic bias. Forget the truth; the best narrative wins. Don't worry if the AI model is constantly retuning itself to increase your teenager's addiction to social media; they'll grow up just fine. 'We have to rely on the data,' says the corporate executive as that executive denies a job to a qualified candidate, even though executives using the services have no idea what proxy data has been used to make calculations possible.For this to work, all of the 'freedom and openness' in the previous paragraph would have to be worked through. The Internet would need to be weaponized against COVID-19. The problem is that once you weaponize the information, it is a weapon. And this weapon would be more powerful than any we've seen in information age warfare.Socratic Debate Is Called ForOne of the great things about the current state of the Internet is that it allows us to hold moderated Socratic debates on important topics. So What is your thesis? It's time for a Socratic debate.Take the Survey If the survey is not visible, click here[1]. Author's note:This is not a sponsored post. I am the author of this article and it expresses my own opinions. I am not, nor is my company, receiving compensation for it. urn:contentItem:5Y3H-TMR1-JB20-G3HX-00000-00Coronavirus Death Toll Rises; Iowa Caucus Countdown; USMCA in Focus; Tech Earnings in Focus; Facebook Euro Trip; KFC Teams up with Beyond Meat; A Hot Commodity; Sylvester Goes Silver; Bring It On; Gold Rush Hits Miami; Kanye's Super Bowl Service; Aging Gracefully2020-01-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTJames Freeman, Ryan Payne, Kelly Jane Torrance, Dan Morgan, Lauren Lopez, Danielle DelPinoNEWSDomestic013003cb.231Coronavirus Death Toll Rises; Iowa Caucus Countdown; USMCA in Focus; Tech Earnings in Focus; Facebook Euro Trip; KFC Teams up with Beyond Meat; A Hot Commodity; Sylvester Goes Silver; Bring It On; Gold Rush Hits Miami; Kanye's Super Bowl Service; Aging GracefullyDagen McDowell, Lauren Simonetti, Kristina Partsinevelos, Deirdre Bolton, James Freeman, Andrew Krasny, Cheryl Casone

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, sitting in for Maria Bartiromo, who is on her way to Miami, Florida for the Super Bowl. We will both be live from Florida -- from South Beach tomorrow.

And it's Thursday right now, January 30th.

Your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern

Coronavirus outbreak, the death toll rising to 170 and more than 7,700 cases confirmed. Japan, confirming two people testing positive without showing any symptoms. We have the very latest.

Futures are under pressure as concerns about that virus and its impact on global economy grows. Major indices ending yesterday mixed after the Federal Reserve chief Jay Powell said that the coronavirus may pose risks to the global economic growth.

The corona virus hitting markets in Europe. You have losses across the board, all north of 1 percent losses there in England, France, and Germany.

And the Bank of England holding interest rates steady saying more stimulus not needed right now and says it sees signs of economic growth following December's election.

It was right across the board in Asia overnight as more businesses are shutting down due to the spreading virus. You have the Hang Seng losing more than 2.5 percent in Hong Kong. China's composite remains closed for the lunar new year.

Earnings in focus. Verizon with a beat on revenue but a miss on earnings, adding wireless costumers will be taking another hit on Yahoo. Coca-Cola out with a beat on revenue driven by strong demand for soft drinks, teas, and coffees.

And UPS, a slight miss on revenue but saying it saw boost from Amazon shipments over the holidays.

And Facebook under pressure, this after reporting slowing growth and a surge in expenses.

And Tesla, look at the stock, surging. Up 9.5 percent in premarket trading after reporting its second straight quarter of profits, and saying it will sell more than half a million vehicles this year.

Hear to break it all down with me Payne Capital Management president Ryan Payne; "New York Post" editorial member Kelly Jane Torrance is sitting in. Thank you Kelly -- for being here. And "Wall Street Journal" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman. All here.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good morning.

MCDOWELL: And I will do my Nancy Grace imitation within the next hour.

FREEMAN: Oh.

MCDOWELL: So hang on to that.

RYAN PAYNE, PRESIDENT, PAYNE CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: Ok.

MCDOWELL: It was one of my favorite moments of the last well, lifetime.

Lauren Simonetti meantime has some of the top stories we're watching this morning -- Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CPRD: And we start with the coronavirus -- Dagen. The death toll rising to 170 in China, more than 7,700 infected.

This as three Japanese evacuees from Wuhan, China tested positive for the virus. Two had no symptoms whatsoever -- that's a scary thought for a lot of people. More than a dozen airlines around the globe now canceling flights to China.

The White House is forming a task force to monitor the virus. The World Health Organization will meet today to consider declaring this a public health emergency. Americans returning from China now under a three-day voluntary quarantine. And that is the plane they got off of yesterday.

Let's take a live look right now of a cruise ship in Italy where 6,000 people are being held as two passengers are being checked there. So this is a worldwide situation. Carnival Cruise Lines is down 6.5 percent.

Federal agents making quite a find -- an alleged drug smuggling tunnel along southern border. Check this out -- it's said to be the longest ever discovered in that area. It stretched from Tijuana Mexico into San Diego County, California. Pretty sophisticated. It had a rail system, air vents and electricity inside as you can see. No arrests have been made in connection with the tunnel.

And this, Dagen -- six suspects arrested in connection with the $7 million fentanyl ring are now out on bail, thanks to new laws right here in New York. The suspected dealers were taken into custody during a raid in Upper Manhattan this week. Prosecutors believe the drugs were going to be sold on the streets of New York and New England. But because of new laws they were released without bail.

And a Japanese billionaire looking to take his soulmate to the stars. He's pulled the plug on this search. The billionaire backing out of a documentary search for a girlfriend to take the voyage around the moon with him on a SpaceX flight. Get this -- 28,000 people applied to be his girlfriend. He thanks them for their interest -- Dagen. But he says, you know what, it was a little selfish of me. We're not going to do this. He backed out.

Md: You don't think he did it for attention? That is impossible.

Thank you -- Lauren.

Turning to 2020, we are just five days away from the Iowa caucuses. A new Monmouth University poll shows that Vice President Joe Biden and Senator Bernie Sanders in a virtual dead heat. The former vice president is polling at 23 percent; Senator Sanders at 21 percent. They're followed by Pete Buttigieg, Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar.

Meantime, I want to show you this. Joe Biden got in a little testy exchange with a voter in Iowa. Take a look at this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What are you going to do about climate change? You say you're against pipelines. But then you want to replace these gas lines. That's not going to work.

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: No, no, no.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We've got to stop building and replacing pipelines.

BIDEN: You have to go vote for someone else. Because you're not going to vote for me in the primary.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm going to vote you in the general if you treat me right.

BIDEN: I'm not.

Look, you're asking for a picture of me. You're coming up and tell me you won't support me.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No, no, no.

BIDEN: My plan -- yes, yes, yes.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I said I'm going to support in the general.

BIDEN: In the general.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Right.

BIDEN: I'm looking for a primary.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Kelly -- it gets better. So he got a pat, a poke and then he grabbed his coat like this which sets Joe Biden -- he likes to put it, you know, he is friendly guy.

KELLY JANE TORRANCE, EDITORIAL BOARD MEMBER, "NEW YORK POST": Yes.

MCDOWELL: But he is assumed the guy was a sanders supporter. And the guy never said -- he went, I am supporting Tom Steyer. So it looked like Joe Biden sees Bernie Sanders as a threat.

TORRANCE: And I think the Democratic establishment does, too. They are actually starting to try to get together and say listen we have been very hands-off. We haven't attacked Sanders like we should -- and this is not just Joe Biden's people. This is, you know, anybody who does not want a radical Democratic socialist in the race and winning the nomination.

But, you know, looking at this video, this is not the first time that Biden has done this. He actually touched a reporter recently in a very similar way as well.

And let's imagine, of course, if Donald Trump had done that. I mean you have to say this guy is having trouble dealing with questions from fellow Democrats. What is he going to do in the general? He does not like being questioned.

MCDOWELL: In that video, Joe Biden made the mistake that I try to avoid and often don't avoid is not listening to who is talking to you. He clearly was not paying attention to what the guy was saying. He was like I said I was going to vote for you in the general.

And it just -- and maybe it's the fatigue of the campaign trial but what do you make of the Biden-Bernie face-off in Iowa and maybe New Hampshire?

FREEMAN: Yes, I think certainly it looks like Joe Biden is not interested in hearing alternative opinions as far as his program. Maybe the campaign trial is beginning to wear on him a little bit.

I don't -- I don't think it is obviously a disaster for him. And generally, I think he still looks pretty strong. And I think the reason is because if you look at polling, most people in the Democratic Party do not identify with Bernie Sanders in terms of issues. Most Democratic voters despite what you might see on Twitter and various cable networks do not identify themselves as left wing progressives.

There a lot of people in the Democratic Party who call themselves moderates and even conservatives. So I think Biden is a better fit with how most of the voters out there see themselves and the agenda.

PAYNE: Well, I thin the other question is how is Bloomberg playing to all this? He's going to spend like $300 billion -- excuse me, million by next month on his campaign. And I'm curious because he's more middle of the road --

FREEMAN: Yes.

PAYNE: -- I'll be very interested how he plays out against Biden as well.

FREEMAN: Yes. Yes. I think he's a legitimate contender especially given the really impressive record he has in New York. So it's now just a billionaire self-funder, it's a guy with a real political resume.

TORRANCE: Yes. with the Bernie versus Joe though, I mean Bernie Sanders is going up in the polls. And I have to wonder, we heard, you know, there were some theories that maybe Nancy Pelosi held off on sending the articles of impeachment to the senate to help Joe Biden because now it ties up senators like Elizabeth Warren, like Bernie Sanders.

But you know, now you are getting on primetime television a case that Joe Biden is corrupt and that he is not a good guy and I wonder, are they regretting that.

MCDOWELL: But we've got to move on, but I will say this and the Democrats learned nothing from what happened with the Republicans and the establishment conservatives and President Trump. The more you attack him, the more you dismiss him and say he is a real estate developer from New York City who likes brass and smoked glass. The more you do that and dismisses ideas and dismiss the passion around him, the more the base, his supporters are energized and the more people take a look at his campaign.

Mark my words, Sanders has got momentum and he's got steam and it's because of people like Hillary Clinton and Joe Biden supporters.

Last hour Maria spoke with Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross about economic impact of USMCA.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILBUR ROSS, U.S. COMMERCE SECRETARY: It could be 579,000 jobs -- almost 600,000 jobs, and $235 billion added to our gross domestic product. That is about 1.2 percent of our GDP.

So it will be some major fraction of that gradually phased in over the first few years. So it is a very big initial lift and it's one of the many reasons I think it's almost physically impossible for there to be a recession this year.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: James -- you told me -- I'm going to steal this from you -- you told me in the greenroom, we were listening to this. You said that he made a really good case for accelerating growth in the new year.

FREEMAN: Yes, I think that last part where he talks about how it is really tough to see how we could have a recession, I think he did make a good case. And I think you don't necessarily need to buy his claims about the USMCA job growth. But when he was talking about big picture, trade fights are resolved, General Motors strike over, Boeing 737 Max deliveries probably resume sometime this year -- then you got the obviously very healthy consumer, good policy mix -- it's a good economy.

MCDOWELL: Boom. I was making this hand motion when James --- this was the 737 Max taking off. So you're going to take it off -- we get the GDP report. The first reading on the fourth quarter at the bottom of the hour.

That's why we're -- that's why I'm talking fast. And we're heading to break. And we have so much more to talk about this morning.

Earnings season in full swing -- we take a look at Facebook. It takes a hit on slowing growth but Microsoft and Tesla on a tear. After the bell eyes will be on Amazon.

Countdown to the Super Bowl kickoff, rapper Kanye West has big plans for the big game as ticket prices soar sky high. His Sunday service, yes.

And bringing the heat to an iconic flavor. Old Bay is spicing things up with a limited edition hot sauce that sold out within an hour. You do not eat steamed blue crab without Old Bay, or shrimp for that matter, where I come from.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And then coming up, something more serious. The deadly coronavirus outbreak -- fresh fears surfacing over the spread of misinformation. How Twitter is trying to fight that problem.

Plus beyond finger-lickin' good -- KFC teaming up with Beyond Meat to bring buckets of plant-based fried chicken -- it's not chicken, it's -- well, it's on the menu. That is what it is. We'll tell you where you can get your hands on it.

MCDOWELL: Tech on a tear. Big name tech companies seeing fourth quarter growth as earnings season rolls on. Already about one-third of S&P 500 companies have reported earnings.

Facebook beating expectations but a warning over slow growth is weighing on that stock this morning. It's down more than 7 percent. But up on this 9 percent year-to-date before that earnings report.

Meantime Microsoft shares poised to open at a new all time high after reporting strength in its cloud business.

And Tesla driving to a new high after posting a second straight profit for the quarter.

We're also watching Amazon. It reports after the bell today.

Joining me now, Synovus Trust portfolio manager Dan Morgan. Dan -- your thoughts. Break it down for us.

DAN MORGAN, PORT FOLIO MANAGER, SYNOVUS TRUS: Hi -- Dagen.

Well, they were all pretty good reports. I mean if you think about even the Facebook that came out, they were -- you know pushed aggressively 25 percent growth in advertising and they've been warning us that advertising has been slowing.

I think that one thing that the market really got upset about Dagen -- was the 51 percent jump in total cost and expenses for fiscal year 2019. That really weighed on the stock.

As you know, the stock has made a big run. It was at an all-time high coming into that earnings report so there wasn't a lot of error -- room for error going into that report.

And then Microsoft, as you mentioned before, a dynamite report. Intelligent cloud was up 27 percent. Acer (ph) was up 62 percent, I had estimated 55 percent growth. So very, very strong on the cloud front. I think they generated about $134 billion in cash.

So Microsoft was lights out, they hit on every single metric. And quite frankly, Dagen -- I didn't think the Facebook report was that bad but obviously everybody is very worried about cause (ph) associated with security going forward. You have Zuckerberg going over to Brussels. So I think that manifested in a bit of sell-off on the stock when they made that announcement.

MCDOWELL: on that note, just since you brought it up -- Dan that Mark Zuckerberg is going to -- on a European mission trip to Brussels, as you said, next month to discuss Internet rules and regulations with leaders of the European Union to personally lobby E.U. lawmakers.

What -- what do you make of that? Because again, I am going to -- as you answer -- answer about Europe and then I will ask you about growth here.

MORGAN: Yes Dagen -- so I think it is a really good move by Mark Zuckerberg. I mean he's basically showing that he's being proactive, right? We know what happened in the Cambridge Analytics issue, you know, year and a half ago. We know what happened in the U.S. We know about Elizabeth Warren and all these political pundits here in the U.S. are constantly throwing darts at Facebook.

So he is going over there. He's is trying to feel out and get a hold on exactly what those regulations are and ensure them that he is going to do everything in his power to protect data, right. And privacy and so forth.

So I think his goal is to show good faith that he wants to abide by the rules and by personally going over there and meeting with the E.U. in Brussels, he's showing that he is just not pushing it off and that's not something serious because let's face it Dagen -- they don't want to have another write-off like they did a couple of quarters ago.

You remember they wrote a big check to -- it's either the FTC or the Justice Department. They just kind of wrote it off on the quarter, it's like $500 million or something -- it was a huge number. And obviously, they don't want to keep writing checks. So I think that's the reason why they're showing this proactive movement.

MCDOWELL: Yes. I'll point out that Elizabeth Warren keeps tweeting about this. She tweeted within the last 24 hours, talking about "The stakes of this election are too high. We need to fight the spread of false information that disempowers voters and undermines democracy. I will do my part calling on fellow candidates and big tech companies to do their part."

Because as Rob Schneider, the actor said, that we're just -- maybe the American people were just so completely stupid that we can't think for ourselves. But anyway, go ahead -- Ryan.

PAYNE: Hey Dan -- Ryan Payne from Payne Capital. You know, well, we are starting to see now tech -- obviously the numbers have been fantastic. But we are also seeing things are priced to perfection and Facebook's a great example of that right here.

Earnings are still great but the stock is still down 7 percent. Is there still time to add money to tech here even with valuations where they are?

MORGAN: You are right -- Ryan. I mean you look at the same stocks, right. You got Google, Microsoft, Apple -- all kind of trading in the same range - - 25, 30 times earnings. You got Netflix and Amazon around 60 times earnings.

PAYNE: Crazy.

MORGAN: So is there room to keep going, right?

And you know, my response is I have been in the business since 1987. I went through the whole 90s and with the tech stocks. And I ran tech mutual funds back then. And you know, back then, we're trading at 50 times earnings on the S&P information technology benchmark. Now we are at about 27 times.

So I still think there is some room but, you know, Ryan -- where I think there is opportunities is may be not so much in these price perfection same stocks like you are talking about, but in other areas, you know, like in cloud. You got Sales Force, Workday. You've got the chips have done really well, right, even though they pulled back a little bit. That was a great trade over the last 12 months. So I think we're starting to see the strength kind of throw out in the tech space.

MCDOWELL: Dan -- great to see you. Terrific analysis.

MORGAN: Okay.

MCDOWELL: And I like somebody who's been around --

MORGAN: Thank you -- Dagen.

MCDOWELL: -- as long as I have. Dan Morgan -- thank you, again.

MORGAN: There you go.

MCDOWELL: Coming up -- beyond finger-lickin' good. KFC teaming up with Beyond Meat to brings buckets of plant-based fried, call it "clicken"? I don't know what to call it. But it's a plant-based option.

FREEMAN: Non-chicken.

MCDOWELL: Plus bringing the heat -- Old Bay spicing up its classic seasoning with a limited edition hot sauce but you better act fast.

MCDOWELL: Apple and Broadcom paying hefty fines for patent breaches.

Kristina Partsinevelos on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with more -- Kristina.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: That would be Caltech -- the California Institution of Technology saying that they won a jury verdict against Apple and Broadcom. The reason they're saying is that Broadcom used their wi-fi chips in Apple iPhones and those wi-fi chips infringed on parents that Caltech did indeed file.

We have filed Apple right now that's not commenting but they are appealing the decision, the jury is -- the fund is going to be $1.1 billion -- that's $1.1 billion jury verdict.

Beyond Meat though -- I want to shift gears because I know you guys talked about this before the commercial break. Beyond Meat has announced that they're expanding their partnerships with Kentucky Fried Chicken the launch the BFC, the Beyond Fried Chicken sandwich -- and I just made up that acronym -- I don't know what it's going to be called but they launched these chicken sandwiches in Atlanta.

They sold out in less than five hours. They were so successful that they're expanding it to 70 other locations in Nashville, Tennessee; Charlotte, North Carolina and it's going to be in shelves February 23 or until supplies last.

And last but not least, UPS just put out some mixed earnings. They failed to -- they missed on revenue. Their earnings per share came in line but they did announce that they're going to be joining forces with Waymo -- that is the self-driving unit of Google. They're going to be driving vehicles -- these are self-driving cars that go from UPS facilities and they're just going to be delivering packages to a sorting facility in Phoenix, Arizona.

This is going to be test-drove in the next few months or so but this is big news for both of those. And I will be interviewing the CEO of UPS later on in the day and we'll have clips on that on Fox Business.

MCDOWELL: Get down. Awesome.

Thank you -- Kristina. Kristina Partsinevelos at the New York Stock Exchange.

Countdown to Super Bowl kickoff. Rapper Kanye West has big plans for the big game as ticket prices go sky-high.

And bringing the heat -- Old Bay spicing up its classic seasoning with a limited edition hot sauce but you better act fast.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo.

It is Thursday, January 30.

Maria on her way to the Super Bowl.

We've got breaking news on this U.S. economy. We're waiting on the first reading on GDP growth in the fourth quarter. The expectation is for growth of 2.1 percent, same as in the third quarter. We will bring you that number as soon as it hits.

Meantime, take a look at how futures are trading so far this morning. We're exactly an hour away from the opening bell. We have losses across the board because of the concern about the spread of that coronavirus. 2.1 percent growth right on the money, right on the nose. Deirdre Bolton has more on this report on GDP growth. Deirdre?

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: That is exactly right, Dagen. 2.1 percent matching the third quarter and exactly what economists had expected. Although I do want to say in reading around there was really a very big range because there were a lot more volatile elements than before, as a few economists were telling me, Dagen, including the price of oil for example. So I saw some estimates as low as 1.8 percent. I saw some as high as 2.1.

So in that light, we can be pretty optimistic in the sense that is coming in very much at the higher end of the range. A few things I'm going to be breaking down later for the most part. It's us. It's consumer spending that has been holding up the U.S. economy as we know two-thirds of GDP. The element that was the slowest last quarter, which I'm going to keep digging through the numbers here was the business equip -- or business investment rather in equipment and structures.

And a lot of economists that I was speaking with, they were saying, listen to U.S.-China trade war has taken a toll on confidence, business leaders confidence, they were not so ready to commit new capital, for example, two new infrastructures. So I'm going to begin to go through those numbers as well. And you remember this Tuesday again, the last time in that third quarter, we actually saw home buyers come back for the first time in seven quarters.

I'm going to see if the homebuyers kept up this time. In the meantime, what you need to know that headline, as expected, matching the third quarter at 2.1 percent. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Deirdre, great insight for that. Thank you so much. Let's bring it out and talk to it. Ryan, what do you make of this because you did point out that this was -- this was solid simply because some of the estimates were low for the quarter.

RYAN PAYNE, PRESIDENT, PAYNE CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: That's right. So the high end of the range, which is great. And also, this is the same growth now we've had for over a decade. So it's just more of the same steady, steady growth. And that's why I think this expansion is just going to continue because there's no real overheating in the economy. And go back to James that I spoke back in the green room. The other thing is now we have trade deals, companies are spending again. So that could be huge for GDP coming into 2020. Very --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: I'm going to call Reuters out on this, James.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: OK.

MCDOWELL: Here's the headline from the Reuters report. The U.S. economy miss the Trump administration's three percent growth target for the second straight year. That's the headline. That is the first sentence of their wire report. It is. it is 2.3 percent growth for last year 2019, that's the slowest since 2016. But what do you make -- what do you make of this report for the quarter -- for the most recent quarter?

FREEMAN: I think Deirdre hit it on the head there. This is the cost of the trade fight. We saw a faster growth. We saw exactly that Trump plan in the aftermath of his tax cuts that encourage businesses to invest. We saw that surge in capital expenditures after the tax cut came through. Then we got into this trade fight. And we've seen how we're back to kind of slow OK, good, but not great growth.

And that's why I think you have to be excited now because he has resolved at least for the phase one, the China deal. He is just yesterday, signed the enacting legislation on the U.S.- Mexico-Canada deal. Now you've got the great Trump tax cut policy. You've got the deregulation and you've got trade peace should be a good year.

PAYNE: Yes.

TORRANCE: Yes. I mean, markets hate uncertainty. And there's been a lot of uncertainty with these trade wars going on. But, you know, Deidre also mentioned I think it's important is the consumer. We had record spending over the holiday season. New home sales are up, I think, almost record numbers. So yes, I think that all of the Democrats that have been really, I think hoping for recession because that's their only chance. I think --

PAYNE: It's good for elections.

TORRANCE: -- to win in November. Exactly. I think it was wishful thinking. I think the numbers we're seeing, they look great. And I think it's strange as you said, Dagan, that Reuters report. It's -- but that I think you can spin numbers, you know.

MCDOWELL: I'm just -- again, I've been -- I was a writer -- I was a writer and a journalist before I ever started working in T.V. and just give me the number. Just tell me the number and analyze why it's good. OK? Bad, whatever. But just give me the number. But again, it's -- I guess it is political. It is political in every way. We're going into an election year. What do you think about the coming year because we were talking about what Wilbur Ross was saying, and it does look like that there's a lot of not -- of course, we're watching these futures and there's the issue of the coronavirus, but there's a lot of wind at the backs of not just our economy, but the global economy.

PAYNE: That's exactly right. And James hit me on the head just here in the U.S. But if you look at manufacturing data across the pond, I mean, that's actually getting better too. So, I mean, this year we can really see a return to global growth. And that's just good for everybody. So I think overall, it was funny last year, we've been talking about a recession. Now it just seems laughable which I was saying last year for the record.

But now, yes, I think now we get the global economy picking up too. That's just another one at the back for everybody. It's all good stuff.

MCDOWELL: One -- Michael Kantro was from Cornerstone Macro was on yesterday and he -- and he has been writing about this that consumer free cash flow, that is after tax bills, food, energy, debt service, everything is at a record high.

PAYNE: They save now. American save. That's like incredible. It's been years since we said.

FREEMAN: Yes. Saving and spending. And how can you be increasing your savings and increasing spending obviously, it's got to be more jobs and higher wages.

MCDOWELL: But it's the combination is the -- it's the trinity. It's the perfect combination of low interest rates, which eight -- that takes eight. We've got the beginning of this trickling into the economy. 18 months that the U.S. economy will feel the impact of lower interest sights, low oil prices. And I think President Trump can take some credit for that, given the -- we're now the number one producer of energy in the world. And then full employment, those are three things that will keep the economy moving - -

(CROSSTALK)

TORRANCE. And the energy thing I think is very important, Dagen, because you're likely to have an election this year, which President Trump's rival is not going to be as supportive. Now, it's going to depend of course, if it's Biden, or if it's Sanders or somebody else, but on the whole, the Democrats don't like fracking. They want to ban it. They don't like new pipelines. But this is something that's really shored up the American economy and of course, energy independence.

MCDOWELL: That's what -- I actually made notes when I first saw that Joe Biden video at the top of the hour that we played or the man confronting him about, we don't rebuild pipelines. We don't need any pipelines and I wanted Vice President Biden. He's a Democrat, but he is a moderate. Maybe they only want.

FREEMAN: Relatively, yes.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Relatively moderate, but I want him to look at that man and say, we have pipelines because we're delivering plentiful, cheap fuel to the people who need it. And by that we are raising the standard of living for people in this country. This is a critical part of not only our economic growth but our national security. And we use these fuels because they're inexpensive.

And it helps Americans and it -- but you will never hear -- he might believe that but you'll never hear that.

PAYNE: That's a good point.

TORRANCE: And -- to say quickly, Pennsylvania has seemed just an economic almost a miracle. Thanks to energy, thanks to fracking. And, you know, if the Democrats elect someone that wants to get rid of it, I don't think -- I nominate someone, I don't see how they're going to win Pennsylvania.

PAYNE: Well, just add to it too. It's also a tax break because oil prices have come down for the U.S. consumer as well. There's low oil prices also factor as another stimulus. So that's actually been very good for the consumer.

FREEMAN: Yes. The Democratic debate on this is basically how many trillions of dollars of costs should we impose on U.S. workers and consumers in order to reduce emissions even further? And so you -- yes, I -- you are never going to hear that message that you were during the vice president did.

MCDOWELL: China's building one coal fired power plant awake, that China's responsible for half -- virtually a majority of the emissions growth problems.

FREEMAN: That's where the growth is. We get more and more efficient, we get more and more GDP out of every barrel of oil every year. We -- we're not the emissions problem going forward. That's for sure.

MCDOWELL: The Democrats will do everything to have the cause. But ultimately, it is somebody commuting to work and trying to heat their home with a reasonably priced fuel that is going to get hurt the most. But again, let's take a look, the futures 158-point loss, we still have a triple digit loss on the Dow right now. And despite this solid economic growth in the fourth quarter, 2.1 percent.

The features are selling off the markets week here because of these new concerns about the spread of the coronavirus and Lauren Simonetti has all the details on that, Lauren?

SIMONETTI: Yes, Dagen. Everyone's trying to figure out how extensive this is going to be. Take a look right now though of shares of Carnival, sharply lower down 6-1/2 percent right here in the premarket because of this.

And Italian News Service is reporting and where the 6000 people are stuck on one of the company's ships in Rome. There it is. Two people on the ship were from Hong Kong, they have been quarantined. One of them with was said to be mild flu symptoms, but everybody is just so nervous right now. It's affecting the company's stock price.

Social media companies like Twitter are now scrambling to fight misinformation about the virus. The company says it's redirecting questions about the outbreak to the CDC for the best answers.

Americans spending more on healthcare these days but are actually dying sooner. The cost making up 16.9 percent of the U.S. economy. That was for 2018. According to a study by the Commonwealth Fund, it says a marriage laid out $10,000 a person on average, double the amount in countries like Australia and the U.K. The study also finding that Americans have the lowest light expectancy at birth.

urn:contentItem:5YT2-5WH1-DXN1-245G-00000-00Coronavirus disruption and the 'big tech' debate2020-04-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisCoronavirus disruption and the 'big tech' debate

There have been calls to break up "big tech." People are scared that without regulation, we are destined to live in a "surveillance state." But people are also scared of coronavirus (COVID-19). Is this the moment that big tech proves that big data can be used for the greater good? What is big tech's role in the fight against coronavirus? What should it be?

A grand vision

As I think about how big tech might lead the fight against COVID-19, the first thing that comes to mind is that data is more powerful in the presence of other data. The more complete the data set, the more you can learn from it. Which means enemies, frenemies, competitors and compatriots must all join together to win the fight. This requires leadership, but it also requires something we've never had before: a universal database of personally identifiable information (PII) and protected health information (PHI).

The life star

If you had enough information from the search engines (all of them, not just Google), you would know where people were getting sick. If you had enough information from the social networks (all of them, not just Facebook and Twitter), you would know when people were starting to feel ill. If you had enough PHI, you would know who was getting sick and who was more or less likely to get sick. The data sets would be huge, but there are well-understood predictive tools you would use to give governments and health officials advanced warnings and assessments of risk.

This would allow business as usual until a level of risk had been reached, and then preemptive measures could be used to protect people in a given risk zone. Lives would be saved. The economy would feel the minimum impact. There are many good things that could come from analyzing and using the data in this "grand vision" database.

The death star

No one (not even the black-ops data miners) have ever put this much PII and PHI together in one place. Bad actors would find this treasure trove of data irresistible. I cannot imagine all of the horrible, evil stuff you could do with a data set this complete. It would be marketing heaven, but a living hell. You could mine it to offer low-cost insurance to the healthiest and deny insurance to the least healthy, then do the same thing with mortgages, bank loans, credit cards, housing, car insurance and on and on.

The list is endless. I know calling this "the death star" is an unfortunate metaphor, but this kind of information could literally be used to deny sick people the insurance they need to obtain life-saving health care.

What should we do?

On one hand, this data exists. Right now, it is in many different places in many different databases. It can be gathered. It can be analyzed. And we could save tens of thousands of lives. On the other hand, amassing this database would empower even the most altruistic and good natured among us to wonder about alternative uses.

Big tech leadership

This is where big tech leadership comes in. There are ways to hash this data and keep it anonymous. We can mine the information we need without exposing individual identities - it will be very difficult to accomplish (not technically, sociologically). Big tech would have to pick a leader or leaders, and they would have to rally IT professionals and CEOs across many industries. The big tech leadership would have to convince people that there is a safe way to use big tech's power for the greater good.

Broken promises

I've been hearing about the value of the "free and open" Internet since it was conceived. In hindsight, none of the promises of social media or about the free flow of information have turned out to be true. We have an unending river of unfiltered information that is highly polluted by algorithmic bias. Forget the truth; the best narrative wins. Don't worry if the AI model is constantly retuning itself to increase your teenager's addiction to social media; they'll grow up just fine. "We have to rely on the data," says the corporate executive as that executive denies a job to a qualified candidate, even though executives using the services have no idea what proxy data has been used to make calculations possible.

For this to work, all of the "freedom and openness" in the previous paragraph would have to be worked through. The Internet would need to be weaponized against COVID-19. The problem is that once you weaponize the information, it is a weapon. And this weapon would be more powerful than any we've seen in information age warfare.

Socratic debate is called for

One of the great things about the current state of the Internet is that it allows us to hold moderated Socratic debates on important topics. So... What is your thesis? It's time for a Socratic debate.
