urn:contentItem:5YM7-K0Y1-F03R-N4GX-00000-00Coronavirus disruption and the 'big tech' debate2020-04-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisCoronavirus disruption and the 'big tech' debateShelly Palmer

Apr 08, 2020( Kioskmarketplace.com: http://Kioskmarketplace.com Delivered by Newstex) There have been calls to break up "big tech." People are scared that without regulation, we are destined to live in a "surveillance state." But people are also scared of coronavirus (COVID-19). Is this the moment that big tech proves that big data can be used for the greater good?

What is big tech's role in the fight against coronavirus? What should it be? A grand vision As I think about how big tech might lead the fight against COVID-19, the first thing that comes to mind is that data is more powerful in the presence of other data. The more complete the data set, the more you can learn from it. Which means enemies, frenemies, competitors and compatriots must all join together to win the fight. This requires leadership, but it also requires something we've never had before: a universal database of personally identifiable information (PII) and protected health information (PHI). The life star If you had enough information from the search engines (all of them, not just Google), you would know where people were getting sick. If you had enough information from the social networks (all of them, not just Facebook and Twitter), you would know when people were starting to feel ill. If you had enough PHI, you would know who was getting sick and who was more or less likely to get sick. The data sets would be huge, but there are well-understood predictive tools you would use to give governments and health officials advanced warnings and assessments of risk.This would allow business as usual until a level of risk had been reached, and then preemptive measures could be used to protect people in a given risk zone. Lives would be saved. The economy would feel the minimum impact. There are many good things that could come from analyzing and using the data in this "grand vision" database. The death star No one (not even the black-ops data miners) have ever put this much PII and PHI together in one place. Bad actors would find this treasure trove of data irresistible. I cannot imagine all of the horrible, evil stuff you could do with a data set this complete. It would be marketing heaven, but a living hell. You could mine it to offer low-cost insurance to the healthiest and deny insurance to the least healthy, then do the same thing with mortgages, bank loans, credit cards, housing, car insurance and on and on.The list is endless. I know calling this "the death star" is an unfortunate metaphor, but this kind of information could literally be used to deny sick people the insurance they need to obtain life-saving health care. What should we do? On one hand, this data exists. Right now, it is in many different places in many different databases. It can be gathered. It can be analyzed. And we could save tens of thousands of lives. On the other hand, amassing this database would empower even the most altruistic and good natured among us to wonder about alternative uses. Big tech leadership This is where big tech leadership comes in. There are ways to hash this data and keep it anonymous. We can mine the information we need without exposing individual identities —it will be very difficult to accomplish (not technically, sociologically). Big tech would have to pick a leader or leaders, and they would have to rally IT professionals and CEOs across many industries. The big tech leadership would have to convince people that there is a safe way to use big tech's power for the greater good. Broken promises I've been hearing about the value of the "free and open" Internet since it was conceived. In hindsight, none of the promises of social media or about the free flow of information have turned out to be true. We have an unending river of unfiltered information that is highly polluted by algorithmic bias. Forget the truth; the best narrative wins. Don't worry if the AI model is constantly retuning itself to increase your teenager's addiction to social media; they'll grow up just fine. "We have to rely on the data," says the corporate executive as that executive denies a job to a qualified candidate, even though executives using the services have no idea what proxy data has been used to make calculations possible.For this to work, all of the "freedom and openness" in the previous paragraph would have to be worked through. The Internet would need to be weaponized against COVID-19. The problem is that once you weaponize the information, it is a weapon. And this weapon would be more powerful than any we've seen in information age warfare. Socratic debate is called for One of the great things about the current state of the Internet is that it allows us to hold moderated Socratic debates on important topics. So What is your thesis? It's time for a Socratic debate.Named LinkedIn's Top Voice in Technology, Shelly Palmer is CEO of The Palmer Group, a consulting practice that helps Fortune 500 companies with technology, media and marketing. He is the cohost of "Think About This"on the Westwood One Podcast Network. He covers tech and business for Good Day New York, writes a weekly column for Adweek, and is a regular commentator on CNN and CNBC.

urn:contentItem:5Y5F-3TX1-DYRW-R4VX-00000-00Coronavirus fight is between species, not countries - we need science and solidarity to beat it2020-02-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisCOLCoronavirus fight is between species, not countries - we need science and solidarity to beat it Swee Kheng Khor

This current outbreak will burn itself out eventually, but it isn't the first and won't be the last that our world has to faceSolidarity, global collaboration and equal stature for scientists are the tools we need to triumph over contagion, says Dr Swee Kheng Khor

As a frontline doctor in a Malaysian public hospital during the 2009 H1N1 "swine flu" outbreak, I witnessed first-hand how trust and public confidence are as important as isolation rooms and antiviral medicines.

Outbreaks have always caused strong emotions of fear and panic, and now perhaps even anger after the death of the whistle-blower doctor in Wuhan. But how is this new coronavirus outbreak different from previous ones and what can we do about it?

Fear is normal during times of danger - it's what has kept us alive through millions of years of evolution. During outbreaks, we fear because we don't know enough, what we know keeps changing, scientists and governments can't seem to agree on the facts, and we fear death from unnatural or unpredictable causes. Cognitive dissonance only makes it worse - we ask ourselves why, if there's nothing to worry about, millions of people are under quarantine, for example. Psychologically, we fear things we can't see or control. Sociopolitically, we imagined that borders will protect us from "foreign threats", so we panic when viruses penetrate these borders so effortlessly.

Since 2009, three tectonic shifts have taken place to worsen these fears. First, social media - the technology of tomorrow - is being used by societies stuck with the preparedness of yesterday. Second, trust in governments is at historical lows, further eroded by opaque and inconsistent outbreak responses. And third is a combustible mixture of latent   racism and increasing nationalism that has been lit by irresponsible politicians.

Social media

Just 11 years ago, only 17 per cent of the world had smartphones, there were only 30 million Twitter and 360 million   Facebook accounts, and   WhatsApp had just launched. Today, smartphone penetration is at 45 per cent, 500 million tweets are sent every day and 2.9 billion people use Facebook, Messenger, WhatsApp or   Instagram each month.

Social media has given everyone a platform, but not everyone knows how to use it responsibly. The velocity, volume and variety of information can be terrifying. For the average citizen, given their limited bandwidth and time, it's easier to trust friends and family than distant, faceless experts, and quicker to just hit forward without verifying.

Big tech companies claim to merely offer "neutral platforms" as an excuse to avoid responsibility for user-generated content. But are they really neutral if they are home to a morass of fake news, hate speech, political misinformation and extremist rhetoric?

Entire education systems must be revamped to train the population how to search for, verify and use information. Big Tech must self-regulate and be regulated in ways that protect free speech while eliminating dumb, divisive or dangerous rhetoric. During outbreaks, governments, health professionals, traditional media, civil society and responsible citizens must "flood the zone" with truth and solidarity, to flush out trolls, racists and bigots.

Declining trust

Trust in institutions, politicians and governments is declining, mostly thanks to political polarisation and a general deterioration in people's quality of life, public services and institutional performance. Health authorities and public health care services have been caught on the back foot. Much of this isn't their fault, as science alone has never been the sole criterion for health care decisions: politics, economics and the social contract all played important roles.

Outbreaks are different. Saving lives is the overriding objective, and cool, calm and evidence-based science must take precedence. However, in societies with trust deficits in politicians such as in Hong Kong, the   United States and   Malaysia, or in authoritarian and opaque societies like mainland   China's, doctors and scientists try to dissociate themselves from their political masters with varying levels of success.

Political leaders must work with health care professionals to make decisions during an outbreak - yet during this crisis some political leaders are seemingly making decisions largely on political grounds without giving science an equal say.

This outbreak will burn itself out, leaving us to prepare for the next one, which will require both adequate investment in response capabilities to strengthen our health systems and system-wide upgrades. Universal health coverage, enhanced primary care and competent professionals will not only mitigate outbreaks but also help manage ageing populations with non-communicable diseases.

Increasing nationalism

Globalisation has undoubtedly polarised societies around the world, with nationalist instincts manifesting in discrimination or xenophobia against certain ethnicities during this outbreak. Travel bans, a convenient fig leaf for latent racism, are increasingly being deployed despite little evidence that they work against viruses that have no passports.

Coronavirus outbreak: the plague of fear and prejudice could be just as lethal

This outbreak may have started in China, but it's not China's fault, just like the 2009 H1N1 outbreak that started in the United States - causing up to 575,000 deaths - wasn't theirs. The World Health Organisation's calls for solidarity are correct: this is a war between species, not between countries. Helping China, and every country facing an outbreak, is not only compassionate and ethical, but also common sense.

Global scientific collaboration must accelerate with freer and more transparent data sharing. Open-access repositories operated by neutral brokers like the WHO or the European Union can be trust-building instruments. Academic, publishing, intellectual property and patent systems must reform their incentive structures to reward collaboration, not destructive competition. In the meantime, we can and should help China as much as possible while worldwide, health systems should shift from containment to mitigation strategies.

This will not be the last time the world reels from an outbreak of infectious disease. Health leaders must recognise the shifting technological, sociopolitical and geopolitical landscapes in which we now operate to formulate solutions. Science alone can't save us, but a combination of science, compassion, public trust, good governance and solidarity can.

Dr Swee Kheng Khor specialises in health systems, health policies and global health, and is currently based at the University of Oxford.

urn:contentItem:5Y8S-T2B1-DXY4-X35T-00000-00Coronavirus Hits Apple's Financial Forecast2020-02-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisSection BColumn 0Business/Financial DeskPg. 9Coronavirus Hits Apple's Financial ForecastBy Nellie Bowles

The iPhone maker, which depends on both factories and consumers in China, could be a bellwether for other big tech companies.

Hello, New York Times tech readers. I'm Nellie Bowles, the tech and culture reporter, here now with the roundup of the news.

It was a week that captured the central issues of tech in 2020: privacy versus the convenience of smart home devices, dependence on the smooth running of China's manufacturing industry, battles over regulation in Europe and the lockdown on internal dissent at Silicon Valley companies.

So to those wanting to take a break from the endless Democratic primary jockeying, settle into a good chair, because what the week brought you is a basket of beautiful tech features.

We begin:

Coronavirus is starting to affect tech production lines and demand for products. Apple cut its sales expectations for the quarter, citing the virus's impact on factories and stores. The warning was a clear indication of how big the company has bet on China and how the impact of the outbreak might ripple out into the global economy, explored in an article by Daisuke Wakabayashi.

Amazon executives are also preparing for coronavirus disruptions. An article by Karen Weise and Michael Corkery outlined the measures the company is taking to hedge against the potential that the impact of the virus gets worse. The Everything Store is ''making larger and more frequent orders of Chinese-made products that had already been shipped to the United States,'' they wrote.

But at the same time, some suppliers are trying to lower demand, cutting back on advertising and promotions so they don't run out of stuff.

Privacy debates and doorbells

Speaking of Amazon: Not everyone agrees on where to draw the line between privacy and convenience, sometimes not even everyone in the same house. One couple fighting over whether to keep an Alexa-enabled Echo speaker in the home invented their own solution: a bracelet of silence that jams microphones. Wear it and it's like smart-home armor. The tale of the couple, two computer science professors, was brought to us by Kashmir Hill.

But if you do agree on getting something that records video and listens -- especially a Ring doorbell -- there are some privacy best practices, which Brian X. Chen outlined in his latest Tech Fix column. There are many, many steps required, including getting a burner phone number. And his conclusion: ''If that all sounds like a lot of effort just to use a security camera, that's because the security concerns make Ring products impractical to own.''

In Europe, leaders are very good at regulating technology, pioneering responses to issues of privacy and antitrust, but can it build tech giants of its own? My colleagues Adam Satariano and Monika Pronczuk wrote: ''As Europe has created a reputation as the world's most aggressive watchdog of Silicon Valley, it has failed to nurture its own tech ecosystem. That has left countries in the region increasingly dependent on companies that many leaders distrust.'' Now it is trying to change that and reclaim ''technological sovereignty.''

Not surprisingly, Silicon Valley companies have been making more trips to Brussels recently to lobby against some of that regulation: a new digital policy, including first-of-its-kind rules on the ways that artificial intelligence can be used by companies, Adam wrote.

Some stories you shouldn't miss

Noam Scheiber and Kate Conger had a big story in the The New York Times Magazine on the Great Google Revolt: what happened when a group of employees tried to make the company stop doing work they saw as unethical.

Mostly, they were fired. Dive into the article to understand how Google went from an ultra-transparent company that encouraged employee dissent to, well, not.

The Style section's Penelope Green took us to deathbeds. As more people choose to die at home and more families have smartphones, deathbed photos are returning.

''What's happening now is that people are taking back that process,'' said Stanley B. Burns, 81, an ophthalmologist who runs the Burns Archive, a collection of post-mortem and medical photos. ''But the impulse to photograph is the same as it was for the Victorians.''

Our colleague in Opinion, Susan Fowler, shook the tech world in 2017 when she wrote a first-person account of working at Uber and suffering the indignities and discrimination of a sexist, start-up workplace.

Her memoir, ''Whistleblower: My Journey to Silicon Valley and Fight for Justice at Uber,'' is out now, and the Book Review called it ''a powerful illustration of the obstacles our society continues to throw up in the paths of ambitious young women.''

Marker, a new business site by Medium, is rolling out some great stories this week including a series on ''The New Rules of the I.P.O.''

Kickstarter officially voted to unionize. There have been large efforts to organize tech labor, but many have faltered.

San Diego is likely to recognize Instacart workers as employees rather than independent contractors, according to a story in Bloomberg Law.

A general reminder from The New York Times Magazine's Future of Work issue: Professional video game players are in high demand as the industry competes for talent, and now they make even more money.

According to Newzoo, a games-and-e-sports analytics company, competitive e-sports revenue last year was about $1.1 billion, an almost 27 percent increase from 2018, Robert Capps wrote. So, in conclusion, get in while the getting is good.

How are we doing?

We'd love your feedback on this newsletter. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bits_newsletter@nytimes.com

Like this email?

Forward it to your friends, and let them know they can sign up here.

urn:contentItem:60GB-5X51-DXH2-6000-00000-00Coronavirus impact on U.S. economy; Big tech on The Hill; CEOs of Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook testify before the Congress; Unrest in America; Tech earnings on tap; Tropical storm Isaias slams Puerto Rico with heavy winds and rain; Qualcomm announces patent deal with Huawei; PayPal profits jump 86 percent.2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTPat Brosnan, Thomas Hesse, Steve Forbes, Mark Tepper, Jim Lowell, Christopher BedfordNEWSFinancial073001cb.231Coronavirus impact on U.S. economy; Big tech on The Hill; CEOs of Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook testify before the Congress; Unrest in America; Tech earnings on tap; Tropical storm Isaias slams Puerto Rico with heavy winds and rain; Qualcomm announces patent deal with Huawei; PayPal profits jump 86 percent.Maria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Dagen McDowell, Lou Dobbs

LOU DOBBS, HOST, FBN HOST: We hope you'll join us. Follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs, like me on Facebook and on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight. And a reminder, I'll be interviewing The President next week; be sure to join us for that, and tomorrow. Goodnight from Sussex.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, July 30th. Your top stories right now, 6:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast, stimulus stalemate. Now, lawmakers are far from an agreement on the next round of coronavirus aid; this as the extra unemployment benefits are set to expire tomorrow.

The coronavirus effect on the U.S. economy, coming up. At 8:30 a.m. Eastern this morning, we will get the first read on the second quarter GDP. It is expected to show a record-breaking contraction, a decline of 34.1%, expected this morning.

Plus, initial jobless claims are also expected this morning to rise for a second week in a row.

Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve not even thinking about raising rates now. Fed Chair Jay Powell saying the current economic downturn is the most severe in our lifetime. Warning; containing COVID is essential to protecting our health and the economy.

Big tech in focus; Facebook, Amazon, Google and parent Alphabet, and Apple, all reporting today, their earnings after the bell. The CEOs grilled on Capitol Hill yesterday about anti-conservative bias, business practices, privacy and China. Highlights from the fiery hearing coming up.

Markets this morning, pointing to a sell off at the start of trading. Take a look at Futures indicating a decline of 216 points right out of the gate; the NASDAQ down 95; and the S&P lower by 28.

Markets rallied yesterday following the Federal Reserve decision; take a look at 4 O'Clock on Wall Street. The market was up 160 points on the Dow. The NASDAQ was up 140. And the S&P up 40 points yesterday.

Unrest in America with violence raging in major cities; federal agents will start leaving Portland. In a separate effort, they're headed to help restore law and order in other cities.

And the NBA tipping off today, players taking the court in a bubble at Disney World with empty stands; we will check it out.

The CEO of FanDuel is here, Matthew King joining me live at 8:40 a.m. Eastern on how the virus is impacting gambling.

Mornings with Maria is live right now.

Global markets this morning right across the board, take a look at European indices with the FTSE 100 right now down 90 points, the CAC quarente down 51, and the DAX Index in Germany lower by 289 points. We got to sell off underway this morning.

The German economy shrinking a record 10.1%, that's to the second quarter due of course to the coronavirus shutdowns. We'll get the GDP this morning in 2.5 hours time for the U.S.

In Asia overnight, markets were mostly lower. Take a look. The worst performer there, as you can see was the Hong Kong market. Hang Seng down two-thirds of 1%. The major indices flat overnight.

Some of the top stories that we are watching this morning right now, another round of talks between the White House and Congress on a new COVID- 19 stimulus bill set for today with no compromise in sight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We are still very far apart on a lot of issues. I do think there's a subset of issues that we do agree on, but overall we're far from an agreement and The President is very focused on the issue of unemployment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Republicans proposing a second round of $1,200 checks for Americans making less than $75,000 a year. Democrats want to extend that $600 weekly unemployment benefit, while Republicans are pushing to cut that amount to $200 a week.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi rejecting President Trump's support for a short- term bill, if the two sides cannot reach an agreement by tomorrow when enhanced jobless benefits are set to expire.

Well, the U.S. reaching another grim milestone in the coronavirus pandemic, surpassing 150,000 deaths, now leading the world in deaths and cases in the United States. Seven States reporting a record number of deaths in a single day yesterday. All members of the House of Representatives now required to wear masks while on the floor, after Texas Congressman Louie Gohmert tested positive for COVID-19. Attorney General Bill Barr was tested after being with Gohmert at Tuesday's House hearing; Barr tested negative.

President Trump touting America's dominance in the oil and gas industry during a visit to Texas yesterday, The President toured an oil rig in Midland and promised to put America first when it comes to energy production. The President also doing some fundraising during that trip.

Federal agents are now expected to begin leaving Portland today as the city sees a 63rd night of unrest. The Trump Administration and Oregon leaders reaching a deal yesterday to withdraw agents after accusations of excessive force used against protesters. This as The White House enhances the expansion of Operation Legend, deploying agents to Milwaukee, Cleveland and Detroit.

Fiery hearing, big tech on the hot seat yesterday facing tough questions from the House Judiciary Subcommittee, all virtually, in Washington.

The CEO's of Amazon, Facebook, Apple and Google grilled about competition and alleged political bias. The tech giants also asked about China technology theft. Facebook CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, the only one to say the problem is well documented. President Trump weighing in on Twitter saying he will take action against big tech if Congress doesn't.

Well, investors are awaiting some key economic data this morning. Futures are down ahead of the GDP number. The first estimate of the second quarter GDP is coming out later this morning. The number expected to show a record- breaking decline, 34.1% contraction in the last quarter.

Initial jobless claims also hitting the tape this morning. The number of Americans seeking unemployment benefits possibly rising for a second week in a row this morning.

Joining me right now to talk more about all of that is Adviser Investments' Chief Investment Officer Jim Lowell, along with the conversation this morning - joining the conversation is Fox Business' Dagen McDowell, Forbes Media Chairman and former Republican Presidential candidate Steve Forbes, and Strategic Wealth Partners' President and CEO Mark Tepper. Great to see everybody this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Great to see you.

JIM LOWELL, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, ADVISER INVESTMENTS: Good to be with you.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good morning.

MARK TEPPER, PRESIDENT & CEO, STRATEGIC WEALTH PARTNERS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Jim, let me kick it off with you. Your expectations first. We've got earnings as well as economic data. What drives markets this morning?

LOWELL: Well, my expectations are that we're going to get that grim economic report, but the market's known that not just for weeks but months. I think it has priced it in, still it may be selling on the news. We also think that the big tech earnings clearly are going to help this market either propel a little bit more, regain some of the losses it may see today, as we wind our way into the year.

This is a market where fear continues to be pushed to the back seat based on a lot of hopes relating to medical data. From our view, medical data matters more than economic data, matters more than earnings data. It's the foundation for a sustained rebound from where we are. That said, of course, we've enjoyed a remarkable rebound over the last handful of months to the point where I hope investors are not getting complacent.

BARTIROMO: What about the earnings today? We've got a Dow component Proctor & Gamble this morning, which we are waiting on as well as health insurer Cigna, both reporting this morning. Then we had the technology giants on the hot seat yesterday, but Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Google parent Alphabet will report their earnings tonight. What has been your expectation or assessment of the earnings you've seen so far, and what to expect tonight?

LOWELL: We expect to see tech continue to exhibit strength. We expect to see healthcare to continue to exhibit strength and consumer staples. Those three themes have effectively been boosted by tailwinds from the pandemic, as opposed to other industries and sectors in the marketplace which obviously have been hammered by it. And we don't see anything in the medical data to suggest that those trends - consumer staples, tech, healthcare - are going to abate any anytime soon.

So we do think there's opportunity in this kind of marketplace, but for all those who are looking on the value stock side of the fence, saying that their valuations are so dramatically cheap, that they're a raging buy, we're not buying that. We think that's still a value trap. We still think you can let your tech winners run so long as they're counterbalance buys them good defensive bulwarks. In particular, we like, actively managed total bonds, so a whole suite of bonds.

We like cash reserves in our tactical portfolios. We're seeing evidence that gold, which obviously has been gaining dramatic momentum here is also something that the tactical models are intrigued about.

BARTIROMO: Alright. So then you want to have a little exposure to gold, while you're also having exposure to the market as well as having some hedges. Let me get to Mark Tepper, what do you make of all of that, Mark?

TEPPER: Yes, so - I mean today's a big day, right? You've got four of the five biggest companies reporting today. And when you look at the five biggest companies in the S&P, they make up over 20% of the market cap of the S&P. So obviously as go the big boys, go the market typically.

But, what's interesting to me is that the market has been resilient. I mean, we're within 5% or so of hitting all-time highs despite all the economic speed bumps we've been hitting with economic re-openings and rolling them back. And then the big boys have been stalling out. So you look at the performance of Microsoft, Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Google, they've all underperformed the market since July 1st, yet the market continues to grind higher.

So that is pretty impressive to me. I agree with what Jim said. I don't think there's a lot of value in just buying the index right now. You need to look for specific opportunities.

BARTIROMO: Of course, we heard from the Federal Reserve yesterday, giving the markets a boost, Steve Forbes, what was your take on that? Chairman Jay Powell said that the Central Bank will not raise rates, leaving them near zero. Powell added that the path to economic recovery is linked to the coronavirus response. We're talking about zero rates, Steve, until what? 2024, at least?

FORBES: Pick a date? Maybe 2124 (ph), the way things are going now. But I think it's very interesting in terms of the mention of gold, that's moving up. And if we start to get some inflationary pressures next year or weakening of the dollar, it would be very interesting to see how the Fed responds, because usually they try to slow the economy down when they see signs of that. They don't have that option this time. So I think there's more turbulence ahead than the markets realize in terms of what's going to happen with the dollar.

BARTIROMO: Jim, what do you make of that? Any surprises from your standpoint from the Federal Reserve yesterday?

LOWELL: No, the fact that they are towing the line of not even thinking about raising rates and to Steve's point, 2024, certainly there's a lot of concern that this Fed has to be able to fend over the coming weeks and months, not just quarters and years. And we know that this market rebound is effectively based on Fed fiscal and what I'd call furlough stimulus. Those are three very weak legs for any economy, for any market to stand on.

So while we're thankful for the gains we've received, we think our job is going to be extremely difficult safeguarding those gains on a going forward basis, even as we will remain selective in terms of adding to opportunities where and when we see them, not just domestically, but certainly in Europe, which is absolutely beaten down for - mainly for the right reasons, but also globally, with particular regard to China and small mid cap stocks in the emerging markets.

BARTIROMO: Alright, we will leave it there. Interesting to know, Europe. Yes, that the valuation is - a different story in Europe relative to the United States. Jim, it's good to see you. Thank you, sir. Jim Lowell, joining us there. We are just getting started this morning.

Coming up next hour, Florida Senator Rick Scott is here to talk about the latest on coronavirus and the stalled stimulus plan. Then Florida Congressman Matt Gaetz joining me on big techs' grilling on Capitol Hill. One of those big techs on the move this morning.

In the AML (ph), former White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders is here to talk about the stalled stimulus talks and the conservative bias in social media.

Then from live to virtual, we are introducing you to a new streaming platform for concerts, all coming up right here. But first quick break, and then past due, the back rent is swelling in America as lawmakers offer no eviction relief. Then you've got questions, we've got some answers. Our new segment "Ask the Panel" begins next week. Send video question to maria@foxbusiness.com You are watching Mornings with Maria live on Fox Business.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A heated back and forth on Capitol Hill yesterday, the CEOs of Facebook, Amazon, Alphabet and Apple testified virtually facing tough questions from the House Judiciary Subcommittee about antitrust, privacy, anti-conservative bias. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Can you assure Americans today you won't tailor your features to help Joe Biden in the upcoming election.

SUNDAR PICHAI, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, ALPHABET: We won't do any work to politically tilt anything one way or the other. It's against our core values, Congressman.

JORDAN: But you did it in 2016. In spite of the fact that you did it in 2016, President Trump won. I just want to make sure you're not going to do it again in 2020. I'll just cut to the chase, big techs out to get conservatives. That's not a suspicion. That's not a hunch. That's a fact. The power these companies have to impact what happens during election, what American citizens get to see prior to their voting is pretty darn important.

REP. MATT GAETZ (R-FL): It is possible that at Facebook, your employees do have the power to disadvantage conservative viewpoints.

MARK ZUKERBERG, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, FACEBOOK: Of course, when you have tens of thousands of employees, people make mistakes. People have some of their own goals some of the time.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is The Federalist's Senior Editor Christopher Bedford, Chris, good to see you this morning, your reaction to what you saw yesterday.

CHRISTOPHER BEDFORD, SENIOR EDITOR, THE FEDERALIST: Good morning. I thought it was a good mixture of questions. I was surprised by the substance of the questions, where Democrats coming at it from an anti-monopoly point of view and worries about that, and Republicans bringing up the very important issue of censorship here.

The tech CEOs of course managed to not answer a lot, but at the same time, give us some interesting things. Google claims, for example, that the reason why the daily colors, traffic to search has flatlined since May 5 is because of a partnership with law enforcement to stop any election interference.

That does not pass the smell test at all. That seems either farcical or just not true at all. I was annoyed that we didn't see much criticism of China. Mark Zuckerberg was the only CEO willing to even say that there was data theft going on or technology theft going on. To see Tim Cook compliment Huawei, a spy agency for China, was a little disconcerting. But I was happy with the substance of the questions from both sides of Congress.

BARTIROMO: One analyst at accounting company this morning is telling his clients, heavy criticism of big tech gives regulators cover to file antitrust lawsuits against Google and Facebook. Do you believe antitrust lawsuits are coming?

BEDFORD: I think it's very likely. There's a huge appetite for it in Washington. Republicans who are traditionally the defenders of big business have felt extremely slighted and attacked and targeted by a lot of these companies in Silicon Valley, and Democrats have never really traditionally been an ally for big business against antitrust.

So they've managed to align both sides of the political spectrum in D.C. They don't usually agree on anything on the same side here against them. That usually means there's political will to get that kind of thing done.

BARTIROMO: Alright. So in this report that I'm looking at from Paul Gallant at Cowen, heavy criticism gives regulators cover to file antitrust lawsuits against Google and Facebook. But he thinks, for Apple and Amazon, lawsuits remain unlikely. And Cicilline seemed to suggest that Amazon could actually be poised for a breakup. We'll be watching that. Dagen McDowell, jump in.

MCDOWELL: Chris, the root of any kind of antitrust bust-up is rooted in consumer benefit versus consumer detriment. And The Wall Street Journal in its editorial page writes about this, that big techs' antitrust paradox at the legal test for antitrust is consumer benefit, not size.

And in terms of benefit, I know that The Federalist has experienced this, that you're so reliant on Google's ad network that they can, if they see fit, de-platform you, demonetize you and essentially puts you out of business.

Nevertheless, The Federalist and the vast majority of online publications in this day and age literally couldn't exist without Google's ad network. Back in the first dot-com bubble, you couldn't afford to go out and hire an ad sales team to bring in enough money to stay afloat. I saw business after business topple because of that. But a site like The Federalist has basically sold part of yourself and your soul to Google just to exist.

BEDFORD: Well, The Federalist would have taken a hit for sure if we'd been cut out of the advertising network, but we would have survived because we have a diversity of different revenue inflows at The Federalist.

Some other sites would absolutely not survive, those that are responsible directly for Google's traffic. Google has this thing here where they've undercut a lot of the traditional ad sellers. So, when you used to go to a new site and be able to have an actual program that was bought - sold to that - bought by that news site or bought by the advertiser, looks attractive, is tailored to that new site and not to the consumer, it would usually load a lot faster and those are the old days of selling those.

Google would sell ads so much cheaper and using their wealth of information, target that information, that it was almost foolish to buy traditional ad campaigns. That drove a lot of that business out of business in general. And then it was only Google. It's a dangerous reliance they've created

BARTIROMO: Exactly. You are an example of the impact. Chris, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

BEDFORD: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Christopher Bedford from The Federalist. Quick break and then more of yesterday's big tech hearing as the CEOs defend their business practices. That's right after this, stay with us.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JERROLD NADLER (D-NY): Why shouldn't Instagram now be broken up into a separate company?

ZUKERBERG: Well, Congressmen, I think the FTC had all of these documents and reviewed this and unanimously voted at the time not to challenge the acquisition. I mean I think with hindsight, it probably looks like obvious that Instagram would have reached the scale that it has today.

REP. PRAMILA JAYAPAL (D-WA): Does Amazon ever access and use third party seller data when making business decisions?

JEFF BEZOS, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, AMAZON: I can't answer that question yes or no. What I can tell you is we have a policy against using seller specific data to aid our private label business. But I can't guarantee you that that policy has never been violated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That was Jeff Bezos and Mark Zuckerberg facing questions over their business practices at yesterday's hearing. Steve Forbes, it wasn't just a focus on conservative bias. It was also antitrust. What did you make of it?

FORBES: Well, yes. And I think this underscores the fact that these big companies have not been very good at dealing with the criticisms. They've not done much to get a good public will. Maria, in the old days, the old AT&T before it went out - it was a legal monopoly, went out of its way to make sure every complaint was dealt with. They went out of their way to assuage everyone, make everyone happy. And these people have displayed an arrogance that is coming back to bite them.

Consumers love the surfaces they have which is why those companies continue to do well. But politically, they've offended both sides. And when they've had the practices they shouldn't have done, they've been slow in responding to them. Looks like they tried to brush it aside.

And so they're going to get political trouble, whether it's Section 230, which shields them from liability of what appears on their platforms or something else. They're going to take a political hit and they brought it on themselves, not because of their overall performance, but because of their arrogance.

Now they responded to legitimate criticisms, whether it's Google not allowing Prager to have some of their lectures on YouTube, stupid things like that. They've been very, as Germans would say dummkopf on that and it's going to hurt them and it's going to hurt us.

BARTIROMO: Yes, Mark Tepper, it was interesting to look at both sides because both sides of the aisle were mad at big tech and the Democrats were prepared. They were cutting people off just as much as the Republicans' anger over the censorship of conservative speech.

TEPPER: Yes, that's definitely been a big problem with social media in general. But if you think about it, we're fighting the wrong fight. I mean, we're fighting against Facebook, we're fighting against Twitter, we're not fighting against TikTok. And that's all my kids are on right now is TikTok, right?

That's the fight we should be fighting right now. But with regards to these companies, here's the defense for each of them. Amazon can say that they've lost some competitive edge during the crisis because a lot of consumers are opting for curbside pickups. You've got Walmart, Target, Shopify, Stamps.com, all those have been thriving.

Facebook and Google can say that they have proven to be the only option for small businesses to market their services and products because salespeople aren't going door to door, and then Apple, they're under fire because of their app store. But as far as I can see, their commission structure is completely transparent. So that in my opinion is the defence for each of these companies.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's a great point. And by the way, both sides of the aisle have also asked the Attorney General to ban TikTok. So you're right about the TikTok issue, probably not enough upset about that.

A quick break, and then unrest in Portland. While the Oregon Governor says that federal agents are leaving, the administration says not so fast. We're going to take a look at what's happening there when we come back. Stay with us.

(COMMERICAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, good Thursday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, July 30th. Let's take a look at markets here at 6:32 a.m. on the East Coast. We are looking at a pretty sizable decline.

At the start of trading this morning, the Dow Industrials down 234 points right now, the Nasdaq futures down 109 and the S&P futures down 30 ahead of the second quarter GDP that is expected to show record-breaking declines for the quarter, 30-plus percent contraction, jobless claims also out this morning in 2 hours time, also impacting markets this morning.

We'll get that negative economic data as soon as it hits the table. Meanwhile, markets rallied yesterday following the Federal Reserve's decision and commentary from Jay Powell at the close yesterday. The DowIndustrials were up 160 points, the Nasdaq was up 140 and the S&P was up 40 points. UPS, a stock to watch this morning, soaring on better-than-expected earnings, the shipping giant reporting strong demand because of the pandemic. The stock is up almost 10 percent on UBS checking -- UPS rather.

Checking global markets this morning, it is red across the board in Europe, European indices down across the board with the FTSE down 99, the CAC Quarante down 65, the Dax Index down 320 points right now as we learn that the German economy is shrinking a record 10.1 percent in the second quarter due to the coronavirus shutdowns. The economic data out of Germany impacting markets there.

In Asia overnight, markets were mostly lower there as well, although here, you've got fractional moves pretty much across the board overnight in Asia. A severe tropical storm making landfall in Puerto Rico, making its way toward the United States, Cheryl Casone with the details on that now, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN HOST: That's right, Maria, and good morning to you. Isaias is the ninth-named storm of 2020, and what a name it is. The system formed yesterday over the Caribbean Sea, this storm is already battering Puerto Rico with heavy winds and rain and is expected to head towards Florida this weekend. Warnings have been issued for nearby islands and territories. Well, shares of Qualcomm are soaring in pre-market trading, a couple of pieces of news here, stock up almost 12 percent as you can see.

First, the company has reached a long-term patent deal with Huawei. We're moving a major legal clause that's been hanging over the company and the stock. Qualcomm is going to receive $1.8 billion from the settlement. Company's earnings also came in better-than-expected and company's forecasting higher-than-expected revenue for the third quarter. And here is a look at what is trending this morning on foxbusiness.com.

PayPal reporting quarterly profits are up 86 percent, thanks to a shift to online spending amid of course, the COVID-19 pandemic. A home outside of Phoenix, Arizona just sold for $5.5 million, a lot of interest in this one because it set a record price in that community in Arizona. And then actress Lori Loughlin has sold her Bel Air mansion to Tinder co-founder Justin Mateen, sales price, $18.75 million. She's got a few legal bills, Maria, to cover. And those are your headlines from here, back over to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Cheryl, thanks so much. Meanwhile, we want to zero in on the unrest in Portland once again, a large group of U.S. border patrol agents moving in overnight, this despite the governor of Oregon saying yesterday that federal officers guarding the federal courthouse would be leaving by today. However, the Trump administration is insisting that some agents remain in the city in case they are needed and to defend that court building and federal buildings. President Trump weighed in on this yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Look at the anarchists in Portland. If they don't solve that problem locally very soon, we're going send in the National Guard and get it solved very quickly, just like we did in Minneapolis and just like we will do in other places.

(CHEERS)

(APPLAUSE)

They want to solve their problem, they've got a very short time to do it, but they'll need to solve their problem or we send in the National Guard.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And in a separate effort, Operation Legend, the Justice Department will send officers to 3 cities, 25 officers to Milwaukee, 25 officers to Cleveland, 40 officers to Detroit. The operation is already underway in Kansas City, Chicago and Albuquerque. Joining me right now is former NYPD detective and Brosnan Risk Consultant CEO, Pat Brosnan. Pat, it's great to have you this morning, thanks very much for joining us.

I've tried to differentiate --

PAT BROSNAN, FORMER NYPD DETECTIVE: Good morning --

BARTIROMO: What's going on in Portland from what's going on in other cities because I know that the Secretary of Homeland Security, Chad Wolf told me that the situation in Portland is to defend the federal buildings. The court, for example, the other situations are unrest and violence for other reasons. What's your take on what's going on across the country, sir?

BROSNAN: Well, first off, let's start off -- I try to save my special designation for Mayor de Blasio which is titanically unaware. I tried to save that for him, but Kate Brown's comment that the federal officers brought violence to her community really forces me to make an exception, Maria, which I don't usually do. What you have here are riots --

BARTIROMO: OK --

BROSNAN: For fun and profit, that's what you see here. These are not mostly peaceful riots. There was 28 federal officers seriously injured as of July 22nd. This is anarchy as our great president astutely pointed out, and it is not ever to be misconstrued as protests or peaceful protests or demonstrations. And those are the facts, and we're seeing the same thing in all the other cities, and I ascribe it to what I call the 7 deadly sins, Maria, which is defunding of the police department, the desecration of a police department, the disinterest in prosecutors -- they don't want to bring the charges.

They're letting everybody escape, we're emptying the jails because of COVID, we're enacting bail reform, we're enacting diaphragm laws, and on top of it all, we're empowering the criminal. We are empowering and bolding --

BARTIROMO: So --

BROSNAN: The criminals, at the same time we're demeaning --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

BROSNAN: Desecrating and debasing law enforcement and the law enforcement officers and the rule of law. This is a perfect storm for criminality. It really is, and it's not the Summer of love I can tell you that.

BARTIROMO: You've got police in Oakland, California blocked by a judge from launching crowd control weapons like stinger grenades, rubber bullets and pepper balls. So, the cops really can't do their jobs, they don't have the tools that they should be. Meanwhile, in Portland, I mean, we are still waiting to hear the fate of two agents and their eyesight. Two agents actually may very well go blind forever, lose their eyesight because these anarchists that you're talking about were shooting lasers in their eyes.

What is supposed to be done about this, how do you deal with it, Pat, when the governor and the leadership of these cities will not allow their local police to fight back or to get involved?

BROSNAN: It's mind-bending, it really is and forgive me, but when I hear about the judges who are making these decisions, I don't know, are they cut from the Helen Keller mode? I mean, really, deaf, dumb, blind to what's going on to the violence that's rocking the country to the desecration of the rule of law. They will not give the police the tools with which to combat these riots that are really destroying the rule of law and diminishing the impact of law enforcement across the country.

I don't know how we reverse them, Maria. I was there for the rock and roll '80s in New York, I was a south Bronx robbery detective, I was a gun detective for a number of years. I was here when Rudy turned the law around in '93, I was actually one of his bodyguards. And the fact is, in a matter of weeks in New York City, de Blasio has unraveled two decades of extraordinary work, which just goes to show how quickly and how swiftly and decisively it can be unraveled.

New York City is the worst I've ever seen it, and I was here for the opening day of crack which was right around St. Patrick's Day actually, the high holy day and March of '85, but it's unbelievable, it's sad --

BARTIROMO: Well, one of the issues -- one of the issues is that the plainclothes men, right? I mean, the anti-crime stoppers who are plainclothes police officers he disbanded that in New York. So how significant do you think that move was --

BROSNAN: The height --

BARTIROMO: And again, what is your solution pact?

BROSNAN: The height -- the height, I'm sorry, the height of madness, Maria. The 600 men and women that were actually tasked with the duty and responsibility of legally removing illegal weapons from the bad guys, he cut them. Let's not do that. So -- and then with an unbelievable one-two punch, almost a week later, he takes 1.5 billion from policing and moves it into social service work. This is a one-two punch, the likes of which we haven't seen before.

I mean, there's no reason not for the bad guys to carry a gun in New York City because no one is searching them. The standard police officer on patrol --

BARTIROMO: Right --

BROSNAN: Is responding to 911 calls. The units that search them as you pointed out, the street-wide -- city-wide anti-crime units, they're disbanded. They're sitting behind desks --

BARTIROMO: Right --

BROSNAN: In the headquarters -- or by the way, they're probably at the pension section --

BARTIROMO: Right --

BROSNAN: Retiring because that's going on in record numbers as well --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

BROSNAN: Not surprisingly. You know, when a cop signs on, Maria --

BARTIROMO: You know, it really is, a lot of people -- a lot of people leaving the force, yes --

BROSNAN: And put their hand up, they didn't sign on for desecration. They didn't sign on for disrespect, and I've got to tell you, it's the worst that I've ever seen --

BARTIROMO: Yes, Pat, it's great to get your insight this morning, thanks so much. Pat Brosnan joining us there. Thanks for your service --

BROSNAN: My pleasure, thank you --

BARTIROMO: As well, we appreciate it. Coming up, past due, back rent swelling in America now as lawmakers offer no eviction relief. We are at a standstill now on stimulus. Then from in-person to virtual, we're introducing you to a new streaming platform for concerts, you are watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, from the arena to virtual stages, live music is evolving in the era of COVID-19 like everything else. Dreamstage, a new premium ticketed live streaming platform launches today, allowing artists to perform before a global audience and get paid for it. Joining us right now is Dreamstage CEO and co-founder Thomas Hesse and artistic director and co-founder Jan Vogler, an artist himself. Great to have you, gentleman here, thanks very much for joining us.

THOMAS HESSE, CO-FOUNDER & CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, DREAMSTAGE: Well, good morning, Maria.

JAN VOGLER, CO-FOUNDER & ARTISTIC DIRECTOR, DREAMSTAGE: Good morning, nice to be here.

BARTIROMO: This sounds like it's a great idea, Thomas, tell us more about the platform, how it works. I'm happy to see that you were able to come up with a solution in this extraordinary moment in time, Thomas.

HESSE: Yes, absolutely, the COVID pandemic has really destroyed the concert business, artists are suffering and we want to put them back to work. We -- you know, create these beautiful events where people have the ability to perform to their fans, it's high quality, it's streaming and super high quality, and it's in a beautiful virtual concert hall.

BARTIROMO: Well, it sounds beautiful, Yon, what are the benefits for you as an artist to use this platform. Tell me how different it is for you as opposed to, you know, being in an incredible concert hall with thousands of people watching you, you're what? Alone or with a few people in the room, tell me about it?

VOGLER: Well, I think it's a new Zonra, a new art form, and I'm very excited to explore it, and I think artists want a beautiful place, a destination where they feel at home and Dreamstage will be that destination in the virtual world, and I feel it's overdue for us as artists to arrive in the 21st century. And this pandemic had to be horst in the catalyst to propel us into this world, and it's very necessary for us to explore now in order to connect with our fans and give pleasure to our audience.

BARTIROMO: How different does it feel for you, Jan, as an artist?

VOGLER: It's very different. I've done a couple of live-streams, 24-hour streams with your positions, and so it's nice to mention it on your program back in March. And I feel we can actually reach our audience extremely precisely because through social media and through the internet, we can reach our audience, so in a nice way, in a different way.

And it feels as -- when I play live for a camera, it feels just the same, my heart beat goes up and I feel the adrenaline kicking in. So it's actually an exciting way to perform --

BARTIROMO: Fantastic. Well, I like the fact that you still get the adrenaline rush even though you're not looking at, you know, thousands of people in the audience. Thomas, let's talk about how you monetize this time as what are the prices for someone wanting to go to this virtual concert and how do you make money on this?

HESSE: The prices are between $15 and $30, some of the classical concerts we're launching with are 25, some other concerts, we're talking to some of the greatest stars in popular music will be probably around $20. We think it's amazing for the artists to be able to reach all their fans in this way, and from anywhere to anywhere. You know, fans worldwide and we will be making a lot of money for the artists who have been looking for this, they get the bulk of the revenue will go to the artists.

We will also share their contacts so that artists can reach their fans directly which I think is overdue. We're not standing in the middle between the artistes and the fans, we want to enable that. And so it's going to be --

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's good point, yes --

HESSE: As comfortable for an artist, as playing between 5 and 15 in-person shows in real life. So we're really thinking it's going to be great for the artist.

BARTIROMO: That is fantastic, we will check out the new streaming platform, gentlemen, congratulations, we'll be watching. Great news, we will check out --

HESSE: Thank you --

BARTIROMO: Dreamstage's Box Office --

VOGLER: Thank you, Maria --

HESSE: Thank you, Maria --

BARTIROMO: Open today. Thomas Hesse and Jan Vogler, great to see you both, gentlemen. Coming up, CEOs, they're just like us.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You're on mute --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Mr. Bezos, I believe you're on mute.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Yes, Jeff Bezos' microphone blunder making a buzz this morning, we've got it when we come right back.

BARTIROMO: All right, welcome back, time for the Morning Buzz. First up, he might be the world's richest man, but Amazon's CEO Jeff Bezos facing some of the same tech issues that we've all faced during this pandemic. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Bezos, you're on mute.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Mr. Bezos, I believe you're on mute.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: How many times has that happened to you? Richest man in all, but all the same as everybody else. Dagen, what do you think?

MCDOWELL: I think that, that might be the only thing that he shares with every man and every woman, you know, snacking, he didn't get a question for the first two hours of the hearing, he was like snacking and then drinking, what? Coffee. But just know that his snack bars are made with honey from the tears of humming birds. I'm kidding.

BARTIROMO: Steve Forbes.

FORBES: Well, obviously, he didn't know how to use Alexa to get him through this thing or his kids weren't around to help him as I do at my house.

BARTIROMO: Good one. Good one --

FORBES: And have these stack of issues, and with the snacking, I'm sure he was thinking of those politicians snacking on the politicians or the competition. And I'm glad that somebody could get something substantive of that hearing. So bless Mr. Bezos on that one --

BARTIROMO: Yes, and he was the one everybody was watching because he hasn't testified before, so people were really focused on him. All right, how about this Barbie for president. Mattel releasing her campaign team, the diverse collection includes a presidential candidate, campaign manager, fundraiser and voter. What do you think about this group, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Better than the Barbie I grew up with because my Barbie I shaved her head and dressed her in G.I. Joe's outfit. So this is an advancement.

BARTIROMO: Finally, players and fans celebrating the return of baseball. Check this out.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(MUSIC)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The video going viral, Mark, it's pretty good. What do you think?

TEPPER: It just makes me feel good, it makes me happy. I love baseball. I am so glad we're actually playing baseball right now. I've never watched so many Cleveland Indians games back-to-back-to-back at the beginning of a season. It's fantastic. Everyone out there is doing their best to adjust to this new normal. You've got fake fan sounds in the background, you've got this being done virtually, it's probably about as good as it gets, given the circumstances. So, I love it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we are all adapting to a new normal and a new reality for sure. All right, we'll slip in a break when we come back, big tech grilled on the Hill. What we learned from yesterday's hearing, it's all right here next hour on MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business. Stay with us.

Mar 18, 2020( Axios: https://link.axios.com/join/am-signup?source=aci Delivered by Newstex) Thanks to the coronavirus crisis, Big Tech, after battling criticism for three years, has an opportunity to show the upside of its scale and reach.Why it matters: If companies like Facebook, Google and Amazon are able to demonstrate they can be a force for good in a trying time, many inside the companies feel, they could undo some of the techlash's ill will and maybe blunt some of the regulatory threats that loom over them. According to insiders I talked to, the companies all view their roles similarly: to keep existing products working even amid new demand, provide accurate information and fight misinformation, and to help in the broader fight against the coronavirus.What they're saying: "We just realize the seriousness of the moment and the importance of getting it right at a moment when our services are really needed," Facebook VP Molly Cutler said in an interview. Cutler, who largely stays out of the media spotlight, leads Facebook's strategic response team, reporting to Sheryl Sandberg, and has been running the operations of its companywide virus response effort.

When you ask people at the companies, they say they want to help because it is the right thing to do. But many acknowledge they also hope that the public will start to see their companies they way they do.These companies start with central positions in our new, virus-transformed lives. Google's Search is where most people start their information hunts, and also plays a role in everything from video chatting to email and productivity software to entertainment (via YouTube).Facebook's core service lets people see what their friends are up to, while Instagram, WhatsApp, Facebook Live and Facebook Messenger each help replace in-person contact.Amazon delivers needed physical goods, and also digital entertainment through Prime Video, Audible and more.Apple's devices and apps are helping people get their work done and keep the kids entertained.Microsoft's shift to services over the past few years means that many workers can pick up at home where they left off at the office. Now the companies are pushing hard not just to connect isolated people but also to promote reliable information that's desperately needed. Facebook has been working[1] with the World Health Organization since last month, offering free advertising space in the home feed to promote accurate info.Google and YouTube are promoting information[2] from the CDC, WHO and New York Times when people enter virus-related searches.Google is also building some new websites[3] to handle coronavirus information, as you may have heard. Companies are also contributing to their communities, paying hourly workers[4] even when their on-site jobs can't be performed, and taking other public-minded measures. Yes, but: Despite these efforts, misinformation remains a constant problem. Already, Facebook-owned WhatsApp has been home to some harmful rumors, a longstanding challenge within private messaging systems. The big tech companies have announced they are working together[5] to promote quality information, but they have yet to offer many details on that effort.While trying to find ways to help, Google has found itself in a tough spot, with the White House repeatedly mischaracterizing and overstating its efforts[6]. On Tuesday, Facebook was also incorrectly flagging[7] coronavirus news stories and other accurate information as spam or violations of community standards, as the result of what the company said was a bug. The big companies also face the challenge of meeting the needs of the moment while also shorthanded themselves. Most are based in California and Washington, two states hard hit by the pandemic. Many of their workers are now also homeschool teachers and caregivers, while also trying to do their day jobs. Our thought bubble: Critics who have raised alarms about Big Tech's concentration of power, manipulation of attention and misuse of user data aren't likely to give up their analyses just because the firms pitched in during a public health crisis. Nonetheless, the companies suddenly have a new opening to burnish their public images and win some more hearts and minds. urn:contentItem:5YHT-5KB1-JCMN-Y1WY-00000-00Coronavirus Is No Cure for Techlash2020-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisCoronavirus Is No Cure for TechlashAlexandros Koronakis

Mar 27, 2020( New Europe: https://www.neweurope.eu/ Delivered by Newstex) Republished from Precursor[1] Big Tech tales that the Coronavirus Crisis somehow will mitigate their Techlash problem, totally miss the mark. They miss that the crisis is not good and not about tech. They miss that to whom much is given, much is expected. They miss how many other industries and companies have contributed and sacrificed during this crisis without expecting something in return.

Spontaneously this past week, a tech op-ed chorus broke out singing a new tune and tale, that the Coronavirus Crisis could benefit Big Tech and save it from much of the Techlash. Consider:Coronavirus gives Big Tech an opportunity to shine -Axios 3-18-20[2];Has the coronavirus killed the Techlash?Wired 3-20-20[3];Big Tech has the cash to expand after crisis, Regulatory threat also likely to recede for now,FT 3-20-20[4]; andWhat Techlash? Virus Could Remake Industry Giants Image, The Information3-23-20[5]. Like some catchy new tunes lyrics, these don't make sense. Why is the Coronavirus Crisis no cure for the Techlash? First, Americans strong bipartisan views undergird the Techlash in the U.S. Consider a recent Gallup poll of Americanspublished[6]3-11-20. It found 77% of Americans think Google, Facebook, and Amazon have too much power. 74% are very concerned about misinformation on the Internet. 68% are very concerned about the privacy of their personal data stored by the Internet platforms. 59% believe elected officials and candidates pay too little attention to Techlash issues. 60% believe Internet platforms do more to divide society, than to unite society (11%). And 47% believe Internet platforms create more problems than they solve, than solve more problems than they create (15%). Second, core 2020 election dynamics will continue to propel and sustain the Techlash. Ananalysis[7]of the 2016 U.S. electorate shows that Google, Facebook, and Amazon's tech libertarian values were at odds with ~96% of the 2016 American electorate's reported political values. Importantly, the dominant Internet platforms aren't outsiders. Their business as vacuums of inside information make them the insiders' insider, and the elites' elite. They are the most powerful political wing of 'the establishment,' that populists on both sides of the political spectrum are rejecting. This all makes the Techlash a strong populist political issue and means both parties believe that the election could hinge on who wins thepopulist vote[8]. Importantly, both parties greatly fear that Google and/or Facebook could take sides in the election and non-transparently abuse their dominant social intermediary positions to steer the election's outcome against them. Tellingly, every 2020 Presidential candidate, top congressional leader, and State Attorney General are part of the Techlash because dominant Internet platforms command extraordinary unaccountable and non-transparent power. As this crisis reminds, Google and Facebook are still allowing rampant Coronavirusmisinformation[9]on their platforms, misinformation that can be deadly. Third, the Techlash is broad, robust, serious, and lasting. The DOJ has beeninvestigating[10]Alphabet-Google, Facebook, Amazon, Apple, and Microsoft for potential anticompetitive behavior since July. U.S. Attorney General Barr recentlysaid[11]he expects to decide on whether to file a DOJ antitrust case against Alphabet-Google for suppressing competition by early summer. Last month, the FTC started a newreview[12]of Alphabet-Google, Facebook, Amazon, Apple, and Microsoft's unreviewed acquisitions over the last decade in search of anticompetitive patterns of behavior. The FTC continues to investigate whether Facebook's acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp were anticompetitive and hassignaled[13]that past acquisitions could be unwound, and Facebook broken up. FTC Chairman Simons recentlysignaled[14]the FTC's Facebook decision is near. The FTC isinvestigating[15]whether Amazon Marketplace is acting anticompetitively vis a vis the two million seller competitors that it hosts on its platform. Tellingly, Amazon faces a new class action Sherman monopolizationlawsuit[16]for price-fixing, and a newcomplaint[17]for tying its Marketplace and logistics services to force prices up. Amazon's recent Coronavirus Crisisdecision[18]to only deliver essential items, unilaterally has competitivelydisadvantaged[19]multitudes of Amazon seller competitors that heavily depend on Amazon's dominant Marketplace, logistics, and delivery services to be fair and transparent. Almost all State Attorneys General are part of antitrust probes into Google and Facebook. In Congress, both the House and Senate Judiciary Committees also are investigating them. At the same time, dominant Internet platforms are also using this crisis period as an opening to bombard the recentlyintroduced[20]EARN IT Act, a Senate bill that would make their Section 230 intermediary liability protections contingent on earning immunity by following best practices to prevent the exploitation of children. In short, the Coronavirus Crisis is no cure for the Techlash. That's because the Techlash is broad, robust, serious, populist, and lasting, and because this health crisis and governments' responses to it, are making dominant online platforms even more essential to consumers and society. ***Scott Cleland served as Deputy U.S. Coordinator for International Communications & Information Policy in the George H. W. Bush Administration. He is President of Precursora responsible Internet consultancy. He is author of 'Search & Destroy: Why You Can't Trust Google Inc.' and currently is working on his second book, 'The Irresponsible Internet & How to Fix It.' urn:contentItem:5YBG-X7N1-DY1R-B0J8-00000-00Coronavirus is not the only culprit for companies' low profits2020-03-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:34ZLexisNexisCoronavirus is not the only culprit for companies' low profits


The lesson left by the fall in markets last week is that there is fragility in complexity. The outbreak of coronavirus, such as the tsunami in Japan and the floods in Thailand in 2011 that hit auto and electronics companies, or the 1999 earthquake in Taiwan that paralyzed the semiconductor industry, have shown us how vulnerable the highly interconnected global supply chains.


This time, the trigger is an epidemic that originated in China, which remains the factory in the world and the second largest economy. It comes at a time of uncertainty in American politics, and we are in the midst of what Ray Dalio, the founder of the Bridgewater hedge fund, calls a "paradigm shift" for both markets and economies. This is a new era in which a few of the old rules will apply.
Last week, Goldman Sachs warned investors not to expect us to expect us to grow profits from Us companies by this year, mostly because of the growing impact of the virus. However, I wonder how much profit growth can be expected in large corporations even after the contagions run out and the results of The November uses' US presidential election are known.
In this new and unstable era, the main forces that pushed profit margins over the past 40 years—globalization, increased concentration of companies, the lowest tax burden for companies but not for workers, and the largest portion of wealth for companies and not for employees—they face adverse factors.
The substantial margins obtained by today's highly optimized and complex multinationals depend heavily on their ability to manufacture in China, sell in the U.S. and Europe, and accumulate wealth wherever they are most convenient, particularly in favourable tax destinations such as Hong Kong, Dublin or the Cayman Islands.
As Gavekal founding partner Charles Gave said in a note to customers last week, these companies were perfected and are as efficient as English rugby player Manu Tuilagi. "However, as England fans well know, the problem with Tuilagi is that as a result of his injuries he can hardly ever wear the white shirt. The more optimized a system is, the more fragile it could become."
I wonder years ago when the fragility of complex global multinationals will force them to change their business models, and I think we have reached that point. I believe the coronavirus will accelerate the decoupling of the economic ecosystems of the U.S. and China, so it will increase regionalization and production localization. That could give rise to "less efficient but more resilient supply chains," says Mike Pyle, chief global investment strategist at BlackRock. He also believes that the trend towards decoupling and deglobalization will accelerate as a result of the virus.
If decoupling continues, multinational companies will have to make costly decisions about labor, productivity and transportation in order to disassociate themselves from China. That's something many investors have, given that the two potential winners of the U.S. presidential election, Donald Trump or Bernie Sanders (whom many now consider the Democratic favorite), believe that greater nationalism would be positive Economic.
Sanders and many other Democrats would also like to reduce the concentration of businesses, which helps raise margins but reduced government tax collection, worker stake in revenue, and competition. Many on both sides of the spectrumAmerican politicians (not to mention in Europe) would be happy to curb the power of the big tech companies— which are responsible for most of the S&P; 500—for a variety of policy reasons, from national security and competition to privacy and tax justice.
The fiscal policy of "impoverishing the neighbor" (to which the U.S. surrendered in 2017 with Trump's tax cuts and regulatory changes) reinforced companies' margins for decades. But that also seems to be changing: some European countries are taxing tech giants, the OECD is pressuring member states to collaborate with new digital tax rules, and states like California are looking at strategies like a digital dividend tax. In a world where populists gain influence, I find it hard to imagine that they will not raise corporate taxes or workers' share of income.
Meanwhile, the spectre of slower growth, or even a recession by November, increases the chances of Sanders being elected president. Even if Trump is re-elected or the Fed approves further quantitative easing, I doubt that American companies' profit margins will return to the levels close to where they have been in recent years.
